﻿CHARTER and CODE OF ORDINANCES CITY OF POWDER SPRINGS, GEORGIA ____________ Replacement Volume Including Supplement No. 1 ____________ Published in 1987 by Order of the Mayor and Council Reprinted 1993
OFFICIALS of the CITY OF POWDER SPRINGS, GEORGIA AT THE TIME OF THIS CODIFICATION ____________ Richard Sailors Mayor ____________ Harold Norris Al Brewer Paul Bourassa George Ford Jim Bedsole City Council ____________ Roy E. Barnes City Attorney ____________ Leila Stephens City Clerk PREFACE

PREFACE This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the ordinances of the city of a general and permanent nature. Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1972 Code, as supplemented through September 18, 1978, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the Mayor and Council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the Comparative Tables appearing in the back of this volume, the reader can locate any section of the 1972 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Footnotes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state laws have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this volume. Numbering System The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and municipal codes. Each section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash, the figure before the dash referring to the chapter number and the figure after the dash referring to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-1 and the tenth section of Chapter 5 is 5-10. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place simply by using the decimal system for amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three sections that would logically come between Sections 3-8 and 3-9 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 3-8.1, 3-8.2 and 3-8.3, respectively. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 6 and 7, it will be designated as Chapter 6.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. Indices The indices have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by municipal officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within each index which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. Looseleaf Supplements A special feature of this Code to which the attention of the user is especially directed is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing for the Code. With this system, the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be properly edited and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the Code, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. Each such amendment, when incorporated into this Code, may be cited as a part hereof. The successful maintenance of this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. Acknowledgments The publication of this Code was under the direct supervision of B. Meade White, Supervising Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. The publishers are most grateful to Mr. Herman Hill, the former City Manager, and Roy E. Barnes, City Attorney, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this Code. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publishers have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the City readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the City's affairs. MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION Tallahassee, Florida SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Included." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omitted." By adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.
CHARTER[1]

div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Powder Springs, Georgia," and may be so cited. (Code 1972, § 1-101) Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction. In the construction of this Code and all ordinances amending the same, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the governing body: Bonds. When a bond is required by law, an undertaking in writing, without seal, is sufficient; and in all bonds where the names of the obligers do not appear in the bond, but are subscribed thereto, they are bound thereby. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(1). City. The term "city" shall mean the City of Powder Springs, Georgia. Where appropriate, it shall also mean duly authorized officials, officers and employees of the city. Computation of time. Except as otherwise provided by time period computations, when a period of time measured in days, weeks, months, years, or other measurements of time except hours is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, the first day shall not be counted but the last day shall be counted; and, if the last day falls on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action falls on a public and legal holiday as set forth in the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, section 1-4-1, as amended, the party having the privilege or duty shall have through the next business day to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven (7) days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(3). Council, city council, mayor and council, governing authority, governing body. The terms "council," "city council," "mayor and council," "governing authority" and "governing body" shall mean the mayor and council of the City of Powder Springs, Georgia. County. The term "county" shall mean Cobb County, Georgia. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision of this Code requires an official or the head of a department of the city to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the official or head of the department to designate, delegate, and authorize subordinates to do the required act or perform the required duty unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. Gender. A word importing one (1) gender shall extend and be applied to the other genders, except where inappropriate. Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirement adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. Keeper, proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons as the term "person" is defined herein, whether acting by themselves or through an agent or employee. Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. Number. A word importing only the singular number may extend and be applied to several persons or things as well as to one (1) person or thing. Oath. The word "oath" shall include an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." Or, and. The word "or" may be read "and" and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. Owner. The word "owner" applied to a building or land shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or person in possession under a bond for title. Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships, receivers, trustees and personal representatives, and to bodies politic and corporate, as well as to individuals. Personal property. The words "personal property" shall include every species of property except real property, as herein defined. Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. Public place. The words "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, schoolyard or open space adjacent thereto, or any open area. Real property. The words "real property" shall include lands, tenements, and hereditaments. Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. Signature, subscription. The "signature" or "subscription" of a person shall include a mark intended as such when the person cannot write. State. The term "state," in reference to a political entity, shall mean the State of Georgia. Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city. Tenant, occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies the whole or a part of, such building or land, either alone or with others. Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. Title of officer or official. Whenever the title of an officer is given, it shall be construed as though the words "of the City of Powder Springs" were added. Week. The word "week" shall mean seven (7) calendar days. Written, in writing. The terms "written" and "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters, or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. (Code 1972, § 1-102) Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. The catchlines of the several sections and subsections of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections or subsections, nor as any part of the section or subsection, nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any of such sections or subsections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (Code 1972, § 1-103) Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. (a) The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. (b) The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect. (Code 1972, § 1-104) Sec. 1-5. - Severability. (a) The portions, subsections, sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and phrases of this Code and any amendments to it are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection or portion of this Code or any amendment to it is declared unconstitutional or invalid by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs, sections, subsections or portions of this Code and any amendments to this Code. (b) The portions, subsections, sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses, and phrases of any uncodified ordinance of the city and any amendments to it are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, subsection or portion of any such uncodified ordinance of the city or any amendment to it shall be declared unconstitutional or invalid by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs, sections, subsections or portions of such uncodified ordinance of the city and any amendments to said uncodified ordinance. (Code 1972, § 1-105; Ord. No. 2009-64, §§ 1, 2, 1-4-10) Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. (a) All ordinances passed subsequent to the passage of the ordinances originally included herein, which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and added hereto. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Powder Springs, Georgia is hereby amended to read as follows: ____________ ." The new provision may then be set out in full as desired. (c) In the event a new section not theretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Powder Springs, Georgia is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered ____________ , which said section (or article or chapter) reads as follows: ____________ ." The new section (or article or chapter) may then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, articles, chapters, or provisions desired to be repealed shall be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. (Code 1972, § 1-107) Sec. 1-7. - Supplementation of Code. (a) By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete. The new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. Charter amendments may be included in like manner. (b) In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ through ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. Sec. 1-8. - General penalty; continuing violations; abatement of nuisances. (a) General penalty. Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance or resolution of the city amending this Code, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such Code, ordinance or resolution the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefore, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any ordinance or resolution shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed one (1) year, or by community service for a period not to exceed one (1) year, or by labor on the public works of the city for a period not to exceed one (1) year, or labor in an organized work gang for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. The municipal court shall have the authority to impose any one or more of these punishments, or the several punishments may be cumulative, or the fine may be imposed with the alternative of such other authorized punishment, up to the prescribed limits; or the municipal court may fix punishment by fine, imprisonment, community service, labor on the public works of the city or alternative sentencing as now or hereafter provided by law. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code or of any ordinance or resolution shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (b) Abating nuisances. In addition to the penalties provided in this section, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or any ordinance of the city amending this Code shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be abated by the city, as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. (Code 1972, § 1-109; Ord. No. 2009-57, § 1, 11-16-09) Charter reference— Jurisdiction of municipal court, § 4.13(c). Cross reference— Posting bail, etc., § 6-1 et seq. Sec. 1-9. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are substantially the same as ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. (Code 1972, § 1-106) Sec. 1-10. - Altering Code, ordinance or other public document. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, mutilate, or in any other manner alter any ordinance book or minute book, or any notice posted by the city for the benefit of the public, or any other document or record of the municipal government of the city. (Code 1972, § 1-108) Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: (1) Any rates, fees or charges consistent with this Code; (2) Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds for the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; (3) Any ordinance consistent with this Code prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, such as prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic or limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones; (4) Any ordinance consistent with this Code fixing salaries of officials, officers or employees of the city; (5) Any budget ordinance or appropriation ordinance; any ordinance levying any tax; (6) Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance or resolution to any person; (7) Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the city; (8) Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; (9) Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes therefor; (10) Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city or providing regulations for the same; (11) Any ordinance establishing or changing the boundary of the city; (12) Any ordinance regulating zoning or subdivisions in the city; (13) Any ordinance enacted after July 20, 1987. All such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Government structure, § 2.10 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Emergency powers of mayor—Granted; conditions. The following emergency powers are hereby granted to the mayor, with the provision that said powers shall be exercised only in the event of emergency, as herein contemplated, and shall be exercised only for such periods of time as the actual emergency exists and further that said powers shall only be invoked after a declaration and proclamation by the mayor that such an emergency does, in fact, exist. (Code 1972, § 2-301(a)) Sec. 2-2. - Same—Enumeration. The mayor, as chief executive of the city, shall have the following emergency powers: (1) The mayor shall have the right to declare an emergency to exist when, in such official's considered opinion, one (1) or more of the following conditions exist: a. There is extreme probability of danger of destruction of life or property due to unusual conditions. b. There are unusual or extreme weather conditions, making use of city streets of areas difficult or impossible. c. Civil unrest, commotion, riot or uprising is imminent or exists. d. There is a stoppage or loss of electrical power affecting a major portion of the city. (2) After declaration of such emergency, the mayor shall have the right to exercise any or all of the following powers: a. The power to use employees of the city to assist in the preservation of life, limb and property of persons and the safety thereof. b. The power to close streets and sidewalks and to delineate areas within the city wherein an emergency exists. c. The power to impose emergency curfew regulations. d. The power to close business establishments within the affected area. e. The power to close, to use of the general public, any or all municipally owned buildings and other facilities. f. The power to do all acts necessary and incidental to the preservation of life, limb and property of persons. (3) No emergency power, as set forth herein, may be effective for more than seventy-two (72) hours after the declaration of an emergency by the mayor. (4) No emergency period shall extend beyond the next regular, special or called meeting of the council. (5) The declaration of an emergency as to a portion of the city shall specify with exactness the area in which the emergency is declared to exist. (Code 1972, § 2-301(b)) Sec. 2-3. - Same—Violation. Each violation of any provision of sections 2-1 and 2-2 shall constitute an offense and every person convicted of such a violation shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. (Code 1972, § 2-301(c)) Sec. 2-4. - Presiding officer in absence of mayor and mayor pro tem. In the event the mayor and mayor pro tem shall fail or are unable to act, any one of the councilmembers chosen as provided in the charter may act in their stead. (Code 1972, § 2-404) Charter reference— Mayor pro tem, § 2.35. Sec. 2-5. - Reports from departments, officers and employees. Within thirty (30) days after the close of each fiscal year, the council shall obtain a report from the various city departments for the previous year and shall recommend such adjustments as it may see fit. The mayor shall have the power to require reports from all officers and employees of the city as such official may deem necessary to carry out his executive responsibilities. (Code 1972, § 2-401) Sec. 2-6. - Procedures for disposition of municipal property. (a) In the event the mayor and council determine to dispose of any parcel or parcels of municipal property as described in O.C.G.A. § 36-37-6(g) without auction or sealed bid, the city may, in its discretion, sell such parcel or parcels to the abutting owner or owners, upon such terms and conditions and at such price as the mayor and council may deem appropriate. (b) In the event the mayor and council determine to sell such parcel or parcels, the mayor and council may require the abutting owner or owners desiring to purchase any such parcel or parcels to furnish to the city, at the abutting owner's expense, and appraisal of the parcel or sought to be purchased, such appraisal to be performed by an appraiser approved by the city and licensed or certified pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 43-39(A)-1 et seq. (Ord. No. 93-29, 10-18-93) Editor's note— Ord. No. 93-29, adopted and effective Oct. 18, 1993, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion as § 2-6 was at the discretion of the editor. Sec. 2-7. - Code of ethics. (a) Declaration of policy. It is the policy of the city that the proper operation of democratic government requires that public officials be independent, impartial and responsible to the people; that governmental decisions and policy be made in proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, a code of ethics for all city officials is adopted. (b) Purpose. This code has the following purposes: (1) to encourage high ethical standards in official conduct by city officials; (2) to establish guidelines for ethical standards of conduct for all such officials by setting forth those acts or actions that are incompatible with the best interest of the city; (3) to require disclosure by such officials of private financial or other interest in manners affect the city; and (4) to serve as a basis for disciplining those who refuse to abide by its terms. The provisions of this section shall not apply to political contributions, loans, expenditures, reports or regulation of political campaigns or the conduct of candidates in such campaigns. (c) Scope of persons covered. The provisions of this code of ethics shall be applicable to all members of the city council, planning and zoning commission, board of zoning appeals, all advisory commissions, and committee members. (d) Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: City official or official, unless otherwise expressly defined, means the mayor, members of the city council, municipal court judges (including substitute judges), city manager, assistant city managers, city clerk, deputy city clerks, whether such person is salaried, hired or elected, and all other persons holding positions designated by the City Charter, as it may be amended from time to time. City official, unless otherwise expressly defined, includes individuals appointed by the mayor and city council to all city commissions, committees, boards, task forces, or other city bodies unless specifically exempted from this section by the city council. Decision means any ordinance, resolution, contract, franchise, formal action or other matter voted on by the city council or other city board or commission, as well as the discussions or deliberations of the council, board, or commission which can or may lead to a vote or formal action by that body. Discretionary authority means the power to exercise any judgment in a decision or action. Entity means a sole proprietorship, partnership, limited partnership, firm, corporation, professional corporation, holding company, joint stock company, receivership, trust or any other entity recognized by law through which business may be conducted. Immediate family means spouse, mother, father, brother, sister, son, or daughter of any city official. Incidental interest means an interest in a person, entity or property which is not a substantial interest and which has insignificant value. Remote interest means an interest of a person or entity, including a city official, who would be affected in the same way as the general public. The interest of a council member in the property tax rate, general city fees, city utility charges, or a comprehensive zoning ordinance or similar decisions in incidental to the extent that the council member would be affected in common with the general public. Substantial interest means a known interest, either directly or through a member of the immediate family, in another person or entity: (1) the interest is ownership of five (5) percent or more of the voting stock, shares or equity of the entity or ownership of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more of the equity or market value of the entity; or (2) funds received by the person from the other person or entity either during the previous twelve (12) months or the previous calendar year equaled or exceeded five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in salary, bonuses, commissions or professional fees or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in payment for goods, products or nonprofessional services, or ten (10) percent of the recipient's gross income during that period, whichever is less; (3) the person serves as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors or other governing board of the for-profit entity other than a corporate entity owned or created by the city council; or (4) the person is a creditor, debtor, or guarantor of the other person or entity in an amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more. Substantial interest in real property means an interest in real property which is an equitable or legal ownership with a market value of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more. (e) Standards of conduct. (1) No council member or member of any board or commission shall use such position to secure special privileges or exemptions for such person or others, or to secure confidential information for any purpose other than official responsibilities. (2) No council member or member of a board or commission, in any matter before the council, board or commission in which he has a substantial interest, shall fail to disclose for the common good for the record such interest prior to any discussion or vote. (3) No council member or member of a board or commission shall act as an agent or attorney for another in any matter before the city council or any board or commission. (4) No council member or commissioner shall directly or indirectly receive, or agree to receive, any compensation, gift, reward, or gratuity in any matter or proceeding connected with, or related to, the duties of his office except as may be provided by law. (5) No council member or member of any board or commission shall enter into any contract with the city except as specifically authorized by state statutes. Any council member or member of a board or commission who has a proprietary interest in an agency doing business with the city shall make known that interest in writing to the city council and the city clerk. (6) All public funds shall be used for the general welfare of the people and not for personal economic gain. (7) Public property shall be disposed of in accordance with Georgia law. (8) No city official shall solicit or accept other employment to be performed or compensation to be received while still a city official or employee, if the employment or compensation could reasonable be expected to impair in judgment or performance of city duties. (9) If a city official accepts or is soliciting a promise of future employment from any person or entity who has a substantial interest in a person, entity or property which would be affected by any decision upon which the official might reasonably be expected to act, investigate, advise, or make a recommendation, the official shall disclose the fact to the board or commission on which he serves or to his supervisor and shall take no further action on matters regarding the potential future employer. (10) No city official shall use city facilities, personnel, equipment or supplies for private purposes, except to the extent such are lawfully available to the public. (11) No city official or employee shall grant or make available to any person any consideration, treatment, advantage or favor beyond that which it is the general practice to grant or make available to the public at large. (f) Prohibition of conflict of interest. A city official may not participate in a vote or decision on a matter affecting a person, entity, or property in which the official or employee has a substantial interest; in addition, a city official or employee who serves as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors of a nonprofit entity may not participate in a vote or decision regarding funding by or through the city of the entity. Where the interest of a city official or employee in the subject matter of a vote or decision is remote or incidental, the city official or employee may participate in the vote or decision and need not disclose the interest. (g) Exemptions. This Code shall not be construed to require the filing of any information relating to any person's connection with, or interest in, any professional society or any charitable, religious, social, fraternal, educational, recreational, public service, civil or political organization, or any similar organization not conducted as a business enterprise or governmental agency, and which is not engaged in the ownership or conduct of a business enterprise or governmental agency. (h) Miscellaneous. (1) Severability. The provisions of this ordinance are severable. If any provision of this section or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of this ordinance which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or application. (2) Penalty. Any persons violating any provisions of this policy are subject to: a. Written and oral reprimand by the council, board, commission or committee of which said violator a member; b. A fine greater than one hundred dollars ($100.00) but less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) to be imposed by the council, commission, board or committee of which the violator is a member. c. Request for resignation by the council, board, committee or commission of which the violator is a member. Each council, board, commission or committee shall have authority to establish rules and regulations to impose said penalties. (Ord. No. 2002-20, §§ I—VIII, 9-16-02) Secs. 2-8—2-19. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COUNCIL MEETINGS
Sec. 2-20. - Regular meetings. The regular meetings of the council shall be held on the first and third Mondays of January, February, March, April, May, June, October, and November, on the third Monday of July, August and September, and on the first Monday of December, with such changes as may be announced at a public meeting and posted at city hall. Regular meetings shall be convened at 7:00 p.m. at city hall or at such alternate location as may be announced at a public meeting and posted at city hall. In addition to the foregoing scheduled regular meetings, the council shall meet on the Wednesday next preceding each of said scheduled meetings for the purposes of conducting a regular agenda work session meeting in advance of said scheduled regular meetings. Regular agenda work sessions shall be convened at 5:00 p.m. in the second floor conference room of city hall or at such alternate location as may be announced at a public meeting and posted at city hall. Notice of all such meetings shall be provided in accordance with the law. (Code 1972, § 2-101; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 3-18-02; Ord. No. 2010-60, § 1, 1-3-11) Charter reference— Council meeting time and place as specified by ordinance, § 2.19. Sec. 2-21. - Special meetings. Special meetings of the council may be held in accordance with the provisions of section 2.19 of the Charter. (Code 1972, § 2-102) Sec. 2-22. - Order of business. At each meeting of the council the following regular order of business shall be observed unless dispensed with by a majority vote of the members present: (1) Call to order by the mayor. (2) Reading of minutes of the previous meeting by the city clerk for correction and approval. (3) Grievances from citizens. (4) Communications from the mayor. (5) Reports from committees, the mayor, members of the council and other offices. (6) Old business. (7) New business. (8) Adjournment. (Code 1972, § 2-103) Sec. 2-23. - General rules of order. Except as otherwise provided in the Charter or this Code, the rules of order and parliamentary procedure contained in "Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised," shall govern the transaction of business by and before the council at its meetings. (Code 1972, § 2-104) Sec. 2-24. - Disturbing meetings. It shall be unlawful to engage in disorderly or contemptuous behavior which disturbs any meeting of the council. (Code 1972, § 2-105) Sec. 2-25. - Compensation of mayor and councilmembers. The compensation of the mayor is hereby established at one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per month. The compensation of each councilmember is hereby established at seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per month. Expenses actually and necessarily incurred by the mayor and council in carrying out their official duties shall be reimbursed by the city upon receipt of the same. (Code 1972, § 2-106; Ord. No. 2000-27, 11-6-00) Sec. 2-26. - Legislation—General procedure. The introduction, enactment and recording of city legislation shall be accomplished under the provisions of sections 2.22, 2.23, 2.24 and other applicable sections of the Charter. (Code 1972, § 2-201) Sec. 2-27. - Same—Effective date. Except as otherwise provided by any ordinance or state law: (1) All ordinances or resolutions not vetoed by the mayor shall be effective five (5) days after passage thereof. (2) All ordinances and resolutions vetoed by the mayor shall be effective upon the final passage thereof as provided in section 2.33 of the Charter by the council. (Code 1972, § 2-202) Sec. 2-28. - Same—Official copy. A true copy of an ordinance which has been duly enacted by the council, signed by the mayor, and attested to by the city clerk, shall be known as an official copy of an ordinance of the city. (Code 1972, § 2-203) Sec. 2-29. - Same—Ordinances appropriating money. No appropriation ordinance or ordinance to alter or repeal an appropriation ordinance shall be enacted at any meeting other than a regular meeting or at a meeting called and announced at a regular meeting except by a unanimous vote of the full membership of the council. (Code 1972, § 2-204) Sec. 2-30. - Procedures for adopting ordinances. (a) Unless an emergency exists as defined in section 2.24 of the charter, an ordinance may be adopted at a subsequent regular or special meeting of the mayor and council after the meeting at which the proposed ordinance was read. (b) Proposed ordinances which have already been read at a prior meeting shall be posted in a conspicuous public place outside council chambers prior to the meeting at which the proposed ordinances are adopted. (c) If a proposed ordinance is not adopted at the next regular meeting after it has been read, then it must be read again before passage as if it is a newly introduced ordinance. (d) Amendments to a proposed ordinance shall not be treated as new ordinances so long as they do not change the subject matter addressed by the proposed ordinance. Editor's note— Ord. No. 88-5, adopted Feb. 1, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1—4 as § 2-30 was at the discretion of the editor. Charter reference— Rules of procedure, § 2.20; ordinance form, procedures, § 2.23. Sec. 2-31. - Rules of procedure for public participation in powder springs city council and board meetings. The City of Powder Springs welcomes visitors to all public meetings and is willing to hear any persons desiring to appear before the council who is not currently an announced candidate for public office. (1) Council meetings. Persons wishing to address the mayor and council shall do so during the public comment portion of the agenda. a. A total of twelve (12) speakers are allowed to address the city council during each regular meeting of the council. These speakers shall sign-up with the city clerk on a first-come basis with sign-up to begin twenty minutes before the beginning of the meeting. No prior reservations will be taken for these slots. There is no limitation on the number of times an individual may speak nor a limitation on the number of times a person may address any given subject matter. Each speaker will be allotted a maximum of five (5) minutes for their presentation. b. An extension to the sixty (60) minute scheduled public comment section, and/or an extension of the five (5) minute limit per person, may be granted by a majority vote of the council. c. After each individual speaker's remarks have concluded, the mayor may, but shall not be required to, briefly respond, either personally or through another member of the council whom the mayor shall delegate. In addition, when a request for special action or a grievance has been heard, the matter will be referred to the city manager (or his designee) who will prepare a response to the matter. If necessary, action on the matter for consideration of the council will be placed on the agenda for the next regular meeting following the date of the comment. d. All persons speaking during public comments shall follow the rules of conduct for public comment, as set forth in subsection (3) of these rules and procedures. (2) Public hearings. a. Persons wishing to address the council or other city board or commission in duly advertised public hearings shall sign up with the city clerk on a first-come basis with sign up to begin twenty minutes before the beginning of the meeting. No prior reservations will be taken, and speakers will be heard in the order in which they come forward upon announcement of the hearing, without regard to whether the person is speaking in favor of or against the matter. b. In accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36.66-5, in all hearings required by O.C.G.A. § 36-66-4, the applicant and proponents of each zoning decision shall be allowed not less than ten minutes for presentation of data, evidence and opinion. The opponents of such decision shall have an equal time of not less than ten minutes for presentation. c. All persons speaking during public hearings shall follow the rules of conduct for public comment, as set forth in subsection (3) of these rules of procedure. (3) Rules of conduct for public comment. a. All persons, other than salaried members of the city staff, shall address the council, commission, or other public body in the following manner: 1. State his/her name and address. 2. If requested by the council, the speaker may be required to state: (i) Whether he/she is speaking for himself/herself or for another; (ii) If he/she represents an organization or represents a policy established by an organization or governing body and whether he/she is being compensated by the person(s) for whom he/she speaks; (iii) Whether he/she or any member of his/her immediate family has a personal interest in the pending matter. b. All remarks shall be made to the council as a body and addressed through the mayor. Remarks shall not be made to a particular council member. c. Questions from council members and/or the city manager may be asked for clarification. However, no person shall be permitted to enter into any discussion, either directly or through a member of the council, without permission of the mayor. d. No person shall be allowed to make impertinent, derogatory, offensive or slanderous remarks while addressing the council. 1. A person may be barred from further speaking before the council in that meeting if his/her conduct is deemed out of order; 2. A person, once barred for improper conduct, shall not be permitted to continue or again address the council in that meeting unless a majority vote of the council allows; 3. In the event the speaker thus barred fails to obey the ruling, the mayor may take such action as is deemed appropriate, including the removal of such person from the assembly; 4. The council may bar a person from addressing council meetings for up to sixty (60) days for improper conduct; 5. A person barred by the council for this period may request a hearing by written request to the mayor stating the reason(s) for a reversal of the decision; 6. The hearing shall be placed on the agenda and heard by the council. A four-fifths ( 4/5 ) vote of the entire council shall be required to overturn the previous decision to bar the person(s). (Ord. No. 97-18, 9-18-97) Secs. 2-32—2-39. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - CITY DEPARTMENTS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Development authority, § 15-1 et seq.; planning and zoning commission, § 15-5 et seq.
Sec. 2-40. - Departmental organization. The administrative and operating departments of the city shall be the administrative services department, utilities and public works department, police department, finance department, community development department, economic development department, and parks and recreation department. (Code 1972, § 3-101; Ord. No. 2014-023, § 1, 11-3-14 ; Ord. No. 2017-009 , § 1, 4-17-17) Sec. 2-41. - Responsibility of department heads. Every department head is immediately responsible to the city manager for the effective administration of such department head's respective department unless prohibited by an ordinance, rule, regulation or policy of the council. (Code 1972, § 3-104) Sec. 2-42. - Administrative services department—Functions. The administrative services department shall perform all administrative duties for the council and for the city which are not expressly assigned by law or this Code to another department or officer. All such duties of the administrative services department shall be performed under the direction of the city manager with the assistance of the assistant city manager, the city clerk, and such other employees as the city manager may designate. The duties of the administrative services department shall include overseeing municipal court functions and personnel human resources functions and personnel, information technology functions and personnel, the city manager's executive assistant, and the city hall receptionist. (Code 1972, § 3-15; Ord. No. 2014-023, § 2, 11-3-14 ) Sec. 2-42.1. - Same—Assistant city manager's duties. The assistant city manager shall: (1) Assist and consult with the city manager as required, and when so directed in writing by the city manager, shall supervise the administrative services department; and (2) Supervise special projects and perform such other duties and responsibilities as may be required. (Ord. No. 97-15, 6-16-97; Ord. No. 2009-006, 2-2-09; Ord. No. 2014-023, § 3, 11-3-14 ) Sec. 2-43. - Same—City clerk's duties generally. The city clerk shall: (1) Perform the duties conferred upon such officer by section 3.13 and any other applicable sections of the charter. (2) Keep true and accurate books of accounts of the dealings and transactions of the city, which books shall show at all times the true condition of the city, its resources and liabilities and the disposition and use of the monies coming under the control of the city. (3) Keep or cause to be kept in a safe place all monies, records and accounts. (4) Disburse funds for the various purposes of the city only when an appropriation for such purpose has been made in the annual budget and the disbursement is authorized by the council. (5) Perform such other duties as the council may from time to time require. (Code 1972, § 3-106) Sec. 2-44. - Same—Records retention and disposition. (a) City records of taxes, departmental dockets and logs, police permanent records, and contracts, and minutes of city council meetings shall be retained indefinitely. (b) All records of city payables, including all bills and invoices of every type, shall be retained for a period of three (3) calendar years, and then the same shall be destroyed within one (1) year thereafter. (c) All other records, correspondence and documents not otherwise hereinabove set forth shall be retained for a period of ten (10) calendar years from the date of their receipt by the city, and the same shall be destroyed within one (1) year thereafter. (d) It shall be the responsibility of the city clerk to monitor and enforce the records retention required by this section. (Code 1972, § 3-107; Ord. No. 83-7, § 1, 12-6-83) Sec. 2-45. - Utilities and public works department—Functions. The utilities and public works department shall be responsible for the proper construction and maintenance of streets, sidewalks, parks, buildings, public utilities, and other movable and immovable property of the city. (Code 1972, § 3-107) Sec. 2-46. - Same—Director's duties. The director of the utilities and public works department shall: (1) Make regular inspections of the streets, alleys and sidewalks within the city; make a written memorandum of same; and cause all defects and obstructions to be remedied at the earliest opportunity. (2) Ensure that all highways, streets and sidewalks of the city are maintained in a clean condition; and enforce and carry out all city ordinances and regulations concerning city streets and sidewalks. (3) Enforce the provisions of the building code and all other technical codes adopted by the council. (4) Supervise and inspect the operations of all public utilities provided by the city. (Code 1972, § 3-108) Sec. 2-47. - Police department—Composition; compensation as fixed; direction and control. (a) Composition; compensation as fixed. The police department shall consist of a chief of police, and such officers and members as may be authorized from time to time by the council. The chief, other officers and the members of the department shall receive such compensation as the council may from time to time fix. (b) Direction and control. The direction and control of the police department shall be under the chief of police and it shall be the duty of all members of the department to obey the orders of the chief. (Code 1972, §§ 3-109, 3-110, 3-116) Sec. 2-48. - Same—Authority and general duties of chief. (a) Obedience to regulations. The chief shall receive such officer's orders from the city manager, and shall see that these orders are enforced, these requests and orders and ordinances having first been approved by the council. (b) Duties generally. The chief of police shall report all offenses against the city ordinances, serve all processes, notices, executions, attachments and warrants issued by mayor or municipal judge, any member of the council, the city manager or the city clerk and obey and execute all orders of the council in relation to any matter or thing affecting the interest of the city. (c) Attending meetings; collection and disposition of fines. The chief of police shall attend all meetings of the council and the municipal court and preserve order therein; collect all fines imposed by the council or municipal judge and all executions and demands that may be placed in such officer's hands by the council and pay the money over to the city clerk, and taking the clerk's receipt therefor, and making a detailed report of all such collections to the city manager as required. It shall be the duty of the chief to keep a docket, furnished by the city, in which such officer shall enter all executions issued by authority of the city, and when the same are paid, such officer shall enter it on the docket. (d) Preservation of order. The chief of police and officers shall preserve order in the city, enforce every public ordinance of the city and make cases against violators of the same; keep the streets and sidewalks open and prevent persons from congregating in crowds in the streets or sidewalks of the city and make cases against those who refuse or fail to remove or disperse at such officer's request; arrest all disorderly, drunken or riotous persons and commit them to the city jail to be tried by the municipal judge. (e) Absence from duty. When a police officer from sickness or other cause is unable to perform official duties the officer shall promptly notify the chief of police. When the chief of police cannot perform such duties, the chief shall notify the city manager. (Code 1972, §§ 3-111—3-115) Sec. 2-49. - Same—General powers, duties, authority and restrictions. (a) Complying with Code. The police officers shall see that any person who violates this Code is arrested and brought to jail. There the defendant will await trial, post bond or put up security for appearance in municipal court. (b) Authority to break and enter. The police officers shall have the right and authority, as provided by law upon proper warrant to break and enter any house or place in the city where they may have reason to suspect that any of the laws and ordinances of the city are being violated and to arrest the persons therein and imprison or admit them to bail as provided for in cases of arrest. (c) General regulations. (1) No member of the police department shall leave the city while on duty without permission from the chief. (2) Police officers will call in a "10-7" when getting out of their car, and "10-8" when resuming service. (3) There are to be no passengers in any police car, unless on official police business. (4) Officers will conduct themselves as gentlemen or ladies, as the case may be, in any situation. (5) No officer will discuss such officer's personal feelings about another officer with anyone except the chief. Any officer who violates this subsection shall be suspended for five (5) days without pay. (6) When an officer is given an order, such officer will discuss it with no one other than such officer's superior. (7) Any item taken from a prisoner must be receipted for, tagged with prisoner's name and date, and inventoried by two (2) persons. (8) Any alcoholic beverage or other property seized from a person, or out of a house or vehicle is the property of the city and is to be brought directly to the police station, where it shall remain until it is properly disposed of by the city manager, chief or judge. The contraband is to be tagged with the name and date. Also, the amount is to be written on the bottom of the ticket. This is also to apply to any contraband found in the city. (9) Every item of property brought to the police station by anyone, regardless of whether it is stolen property, lost and found, or evidence, is to be tagged or labeled with a complete history noted on the tag or label. The information on the tag or label is to show the number of pieces, where picked up and by whom picked up or brought to the station. (10) A complete daily report is to be filled out and signed by each officer. (11) No officer shall break any traffic ordinance of the city, except in an emergency. (12) During a council meeting or court session, all officers on duty who are not involved shall continue to patrol the streets. (13) Each officer on duty will keep any person, including minors, from loitering around city hall. (14) Police vehicles are to be used only for city business. (15) A memorandum pad is to be kept in every police car for keeping a record of all descriptions of wanted and missing persons, stolen vehicles and all available information of all serious emergencies. (16) Each officer in command, or such officer's delegate, will check the jail for knives, bottles, garbage, etc., and will make a note on the daily report. (17) When possible, police officers will check abandoned vehicles, tags, etc., by phone instead of by radio. (18) No police officer will call for assistance unless it is actually needed, as in an emergency. If a call for assistance is made, a notation will be made on the daily report. (19) Officers, while on the streets or in public places, shall be armed at all times and shall have with them their badges. Any officer appearing on the streets or in a public place in uniform will be considered on duty. (20) Every officer shall carefully inspect every part of such officer's beat as often as possible and by such vigilance and activity render it difficult for anyone to commit crime therein. The officer must, to the utmost of such officer's power, prevent the commission of assaults, breaches of the peace, and all other offenses about to be committed. When offenses occur frequently in any beat without detection or arrest of the offenders, the officer of this shift will be presumed guilty of neglect of duty or inefficiency and treated accordingly. (21) Sleeping, idling or loafing while on duty is a serious violation and any member of the department guilty of such misconduct will be subject to dismissal. (22) Members of the force who obtain credit by virtue of being employed by the city as police officers, and contract debts for clothing, house rent, food and the other necessary things for themselves and families, and who fail to pay for same within a reasonable time, will be considered guilty of unofficer-like conduct and may be dismissed from the force. (23) It is the duty of every member of the force to be thoroughly familiar with the rules and regulations governing the department. Ignorance of the rules shall not be an excuse when broken. (24) The chief of police is authorized to suspend any officer at the chief's discretion, and such suspension shall be reviewed by the council no later than the next regular meeting thereof. (Code 1972, §§ 3-117—3-119) Sec 2-50. - Community development department—Functions. The community development department shall be responsible for the comprehensive plan, long range and current planning, greenspace protection, intergovernmental coordination, infill and redevelopment, analyzing and providing advice on land use regulations and other zoning matters, administering and enforcing the unified development code, assisting public works in enforcement of technical codes, creating and maintaining, to the extent of available resources, geographic information systems (GIS) in collaboration with the county's GIS that will support the functions of the department, registering and collecting business registration certificate fees and occupational taxes, issuing alcoholic beverage and other licenses and collecting regulatory license fees, administering and managing the building and land development permitting processes, and managing special projects related to capital enhancement projects. ( Ord. No. 2014-023, § 4, 11-3-14 ) Sec. 2-51. - Same—Director's duties. The director of the community development department shall: (1) Periodically review city codes and ordinances and make recommendations for updates and amendments; (2) Enforce the provisions of the unified development code and assist public works in the enforcement of technical codes adopted by the city; (3) Prepare annual reports required by the state relating to administration and implementation of ordinances relating to the functions of the department; (4) Supervise and manage permitting, licensing, planning, zoning, GIS departmental functions, building and development and special projects related to enhancement capital projects; (5) Perform such other duties and responsibilities related to the community development department as may be required. ( Ord. No. 2014-023, § 4, 11-3-14 ) Sec. 2-52. - Economic development department—Functions. The economic development department shall support and coordinate economic development activities to promote and enhance the city's functions, as provided for in section 2-121 of this Code. ( Ord. No. 2014-023, § 4, 11-3-14 ) Sec. 2-52.1. - Same—Director's duties. The director of the economic development department shall: (1) Be responsible for the economic development activities of the city, to include recruitment of new business/industries and work with existing business on expansions; (2) Serve as city staff facilitator and advisor to the Downtown Development Authority (DDA) and Development Authority of Powder Springs (DAPS); (3) Develop, in connection with the city's Comprehensive Plan, the city manager, city staff, elected officials, DDA and DAPS boards, strategies for economic development utilizing the community's human and economic resources. The director shall become familiar with all persons and groups directly or indirectly involved in downtown and citywide development, property owners, businesses and related organizations; is mindful of the roles of various interest groups, and assists the DDA and DAPS in developing and implementing annual action plans; (4) Attend all DDA and DAPS meetings, activities, and events; prepare and participate in DDA and DAPS meetings by arranging for space, preparing and sending notices, posting notices, preparing agendas, taking notes, drafting minutes, arranging for refreshments, coordinate public meeting notices, press releases, and special advertisements as it pertains to the DDA, DAPS and their activities; (5) Prepare reports and agenda items for the DDA and DAPS, maintain files on the implementation of DDA and DAPS activities, maintain a file on the minutes of the meetings of the DDA and DAPS for public inspection and historical purposes, be responsible for preparation of budgets, purchase orders, check requests, and periodic financial reports for the DDA, DAPS and the Economic development department; (6) Research and apply for grants and funding for the enhancement of Downtown Powder Springs, the DDA-defined areas, as well as other areas of potential development within the corporate limits of Powder Springs; (7) Promote tourism programs and maintain files on tourism, including but not limited to, demographic data, community statistics, businesses and key contacts; answer telephone, email, mail, and in-person inquiries related to economic development, tourism, community information, and historic preservation; (8) Provide appropriate information as requested or direct the requests to the appropriate department or agency; if the inquiry is identified as a potential new or expanding business within the city, coordinate with the city manager and city staff as required and notify the DDA and/or DAPS of such activity; (9) Develop promotional materials and advertising strategies to attract business development, trade and tourism. Promotional material may include: information packets, booklets and brochures for prospective businesses, tourists and new residents; (10) Attend various meetings of the Cobb Chamber of Commerce, South Cobb Council of the Cobb Chamber, South Cobb Business Association, West Cobb Business Association, and other civic and community-minded organizations as deemed necessary by the city manager; (11) Attend seminars, conventions, and economic development-related meetings as approved by the city manager; (12) Interface with the city finance director and city auditor as needed to insure compliance with reporting requirements; (13) Develop and maintain a comprehensive inventory of available buildings and sites for economic development purposes; (14) Work to resolve complaints or concerns of business/property owners within the city limits and act as liaison between city officials and the business community; (15) Prepare press releases involving economic development activities; (16) Serve as a member of various employee and inter-governmental committees as assigned; and (17) Provide backup to related positions. ( Ord. No. 2014-023, § 4, 11-3-14 ) Sec. 2-52.2. - Same—Director's qualifications. The director of the economic development department shall have the following education and experience, and knowledge, skills and abilities: (1) Education and experience: a. The director shall be a graduate from a college or university with a degree in Public Administration, Planning, Economic Development or related field, with preference given to applicants with a master's degree in a related field; and b. Two (2) years of responsible related experience in planning, small business administration, historic preservation, public relations, design marketing, "Main Street" administration, public administration or community organization; or c. Any equivalent combination of education and experience. (2) Knowledge, skills, and abilities: a. The director shall have knowledge of commercial revitalization from the point of merchants, property owners, public agencies, and community organizations, knowledge of computer software, and a working knowledge of modern office practices and procedures; b. Skill in organization and coordinating events and meetings and in remaining professional and politically neutral; c. The ability to meet and deal with the public, the ability to work evenings and weekends, the ability to work one on one with individuals or with large groups of people, the ability to communicate effectively verbally and in writing, the ability to handle stressful situations, and the ability to function effectively in an independent situation; d. Skill in using a personal computer and experience with MS Office Suite applications and similar software to compose business letters and promotional material, and skill in creating, interpreting, presenting and explaining statistical information using said applications and software; and e. Knowledge and skill in the application of business math and interpreting spreadsheets with financial and statistical data. ( Ord. No. 2014-023, § 4, 11-3-14 ) Sec. 2-53. - Finance department—Functions. The finance department and its director shall be responsible for all activities relating to financial planning, accounting, revenue administration, and treasury management, and shall have the functions, duties, and obligations provided for in section 8-01 et seq. of this Code. ( Ord. No. 2014-023, § 4, 11-3-14 ) Sec. 2-53.1. - Same—Director's duties. The duties of the director of the finance department, also known as the "financial director" or "city finance director," are provided for in section 8-01 et seq. of this Code. ( Ord. No. 2014-023, § 4, 11-3-14 ) Sec. 2-54. - Parks and recreation department—Functions. The parks and recreation department shall be responsible for planning and organizing recreational events, park planning and programming, beautification and waste reduction on public properties such as rights of way, tree and landscape maintenance oversight, and general oversight of the maintenance of city owned and city maintained parks, recreational and cultural properties. (Ord. No. 2017-009 , § 2, 4-17-17) Sec. 2-54.1 - Same—Director's duties. The director of the parks and recreation department shall: (1) Periodically review city codes and ordinances and make recommendations for updates and amendments; (2) Supervise and manage the department to effectuate its purposes; (3) Perform such other duties and responsibilities related to parks and recreation and cultural affairs as may be required. (Ord. No. 2017-009 , § 2, 4-17-17) Secs. 2-55—2-59. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
Sec. 2-60. - Appointment; compensation as fixed; civil service system created. (a) Appointment. All officers and employees who are deemed necessary by the council and who are not otherwise provided for by law or ordinance shall be appointed as provided by the terms of the Personnel Policy Manual and the Position Classification and Pay Plan for the city adopted by the mayor and council. Hiring, discipline, and dismissal shall be carried out as described in said Personnel Policy Manual. The mayor and council shall also have authority to appoint on an interim basis, persons to fill vacancies or anticipated vacancies in the follow positions: city manager, assistant city manager, directors or heads of any city department, or other positions, and to specify compensation for such interim positions as may be commensurate with the scope of duties thereof. (b) Compensation. The mayor and council shall have sole final authority for determining and establishing salaries and pay raises for all city employees. (Code 1972, § 3-201; Ord. No. 87-21 § 1, 2, 7-6-87; Ord. No. 2014-023, § 5, 11-3-14 ) Editor's note— Ord. No. 87-21, adopted July 6, 1987, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of §§ 1, 2 as § 2-60(b), with the existing provisions being designated subsection (a), was at the discretion of the editor. Sec. 2-61. - Surety bonds. Except as otherwise provided by law, the council may require any department head, city official or employee, before entering upon discharge of official duties, to give good and sufficient bond in amounts decided by the council. Said bonds shall be payable to the city, and shall be conditioned on the faithful performance of the respective duties of said persons and to secure against corruption, malfeasance, misappropriations or unlawful expenditures. Said surety bonds shall be obtained from a surety company licensed to do business in the state and approved by the council. The premiums thereon shall be paid by the city. When one (1) person holds two (2) positions, only one (1) bond shall be required. (Code 1972, §§ 3-102, 3-202) Sec. 2-62. - Performance of duties. It shall be a violation of this Code for any department head, official or employee to fail to perform the duties enumerated herein. (Code 1972, § 3-103) Sec. 2-63. - Social security—Coverage. It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of this municipality to provide for all eligible employees and officials of the municipality, whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of federal old age and survivors' insurance. In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the municipality shall take such action as may be required by applicable state and federal laws and regulations. Withholdings from the salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 2-63 are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws and regulations, and shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by said laws and regulations. Sec. 2-81. - Oaths. (a) All appointed members of boards, commissions, and authorities of the city shall, prior to assuming office, execute and file with the city clerk the prescribed oath. Such oath shall be in the following form, unless otherwise provided herein or by law: I do solemnly (swear) (affirm) that I will faithfully and impartially perform the duties of my office and that I will support and defend the charter of the City of Powder Springs as well as the Constitution and laws of the State of Georgia and of the United States of America. (b) The prescribed oath for members of the planning and zoning commission shall be as follows: I swear (or affirm) that I will faithfully and impartially perform the duties of my office, charter and ordinances of this city, and conduct myself with integrity as a commission member during my term. I have not in order to influence my appointment to this position, directly or indirectly promised my vote or support to any person or officer in city government, nor for any other position. I will not knowingly permit my vote on zoning matters to be influenced by fear, favor or the hope of reward, but in all things pertaining to my position I will be governed by what in my judgment is for the public good and for the best interest of Powder Springs, so help me God. (c) The official acts of a member of a board, commission, or authority of the city shall be valid regardless of his or her omission to take the oath, except in cases so specially declared. (Ord. No. 2003-32, § 1, 12-1-03) Sec. 2-82. - Appointment and reappointment process. (a) All persons desiring appointment or reappointment to a board, commission, or authority shall complete and file with the city clerk an application setting forth the applicant's educational and work background, any special skills or training which the applicant believes will aid in the performance of the duties required for service on a particular board, commission, or authority, and the applicant's past history of service on boards, commissions, or authorities. Those seeking reappointment shall provide details of his or her prior service. (b) As part of the application, the applicant will be required to state that he or she has read and agrees to abide by the City's Code of Ethics. (c) As a further part of the application, the applicant will be expected to pledge that he or she will devote substantial time to the work required of the particular board, commission, or authority, both in terms of attendance at regular meetings, scheduled training, and as otherwise needed to be an effective member of such board, commission, or authority. (d) The city clerk shall provide to the city council any and all applications received in advance of the filling of a vacancy so that the council may evaluate the credentials of the applicants in advance of making appointments. In making reappointments, the city council shall consider the applicant's attendance record and the effectiveness of such applicant's prior service. (e) Further, each board, commission, or authority shall keep an attendance record of its members and report such attendance to the city council on an annual basis, so that the city council may consider such record when considering appointments and reappointments. (f) Except as otherwise provided by law, appointments and reappointments shall be made in such a fashion that the mayor and each member of the council will at all times have at least one (1) appointee of his or her choosing on each board, commission, or authority for which the mayor and council make appointments. No. 97-20, § I, 2-18-97) Sec. 2-92. - Board of directors. The board shall, among other duties and responsibilities, establish rules, regulations and procedures regarding usage, rental, hours of operation, fees and deposits for use of the facility; oversee maintenance of the facility and property; prepare annual operating and capital budgets for maintenance and renovation of the facility; receive rental and other funds; plan for future improvement and development of the facility via a five-year capital plan, long-term improvement plan and a vision for the use of the facility, including marketing and use of the facility; and assist with the marketing and use of the Seven Springs Museum at the Bodiford House as a cultural facility. (Ord. No. 97-20, § IV, 2-18-97; Ord. No. 2016-009, § 2, 3-7-16) Secs. 2-95—2-100. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 2003-31, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 2003, supplied provisions for use as §§ 2-130—2-140. In order to maintain the continuity of the Code, and the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as Div. 3, §§ 2-101—2-112, as set out herein.
Sec. 2-101. - Intent. It is the intent of this article to promote, protect, and improve the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city by authorizing the creation of an administrative board with authority to impose administrative fines and other noncriminal penalties to provide an equitable, expeditious, effective, and inexpensive method of enforcing any codes and ordinances in force in the city, where a pending or repeated violation continues to exist. (Ord. No. 2003-31, § 1(2-130), 11-17-03) Sec. 2-102. - Creation of code enforcement board. There is hereby created, pursuant to the Local Governmental Code Enforcement Boards Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-74-1, et seq., a local government code enforcement board in the city to be known as the Powder Springs Code Enforcement Board. (Ord. No. 2003-31, § 1(2-131), 11-17-03) Sec. 2-103. - Definitions. As used in this article, the term: Code inspector means any authorized agent or employee of the city whose duty it is to assure code compliance. Codes and ordinances mean City of Powder Springs zoning ordinances and resolutions, ordinances and resolutions enacting subdivision regulations, environmental ordinances and resolutions, state minimum standard codes provided for in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25, ordinances and resolutions enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25, other ordinances and resolutions regulating the development of real property, and ordinances and regulations providing for control of litter and debris, control of junked or abandoned vehicles, and control of overgrown vegetation.
