A general site plan drawn at a legible scale which shall include, but not be limited to, the location of all buildings, exterior storage facilities, permanent accessways, evacuation routes, parking lots, internal roads, chemical loading areas, equipment cleaning areas, storm and sanitary sewer accesses, emergency equipment and classes and the maximum quantities per hazard class of hazardous materials stored and adjacent property uses. (2) Building floor plan. A building floor plan drawn to a legible scale which shall include, but not be limited to, all hazardous materials storage facilities within the building and shall indicate rooms, doorways, corridors, exits, fire rated assemblies with their hourly rating, location of liquid tight rooms and evacuation routes. Each hazardous material storage facility shall be identified on the plan with the hazard classes and quantity range per hazard class of the hazardous materials stored. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-52. - Examination of documents. (a) Plan review. The building official shall examine or cause to be examined each application for a permit and the accompanying documents, consisting of drawings, specifications, computations and additional data, and shall ascertain by such examinations whether the construction indicated and described is in accordance with the requirements of the technical construction codes and all other pertinent laws or ordinances. (b) Plan review completion time. Plan reviews normally will be completed with initial review comments within ten (10) full working days after submittal. However, this review period is subject to indefinite extension dependant upon the quality and completeness of plans received prior to submittal and the workload of the building official. Partial plans will not be accepted or reviewed by the city, until all required technical/specialty drawings are included. One (1) final set of approved plans shall be retained by the building official, one (1) by the Cobb County Fire Marshal, and one (1) set, with original signature approvals, shall be placed on the job site and shall remain there throughout construction for the fire marshal and building inspector reference. If the approved plans are not on the job site, there shall not be an official inspection completed by the building inspector and a reinspection fee may be assessed. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-53. - Issuing permits. (a) Action on permits. The building official shall act upon an application for permit without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. If the building official is satisfied that the work described in an application for a permit and the contract documents filed therewith conform to the requirements of the technical construction codes and other pertinent laws and ordinances, the city shall issue a permit to the applicant. (b) Refusal to issue a permit. If the application for a permit and the accompanying contract documents describing the work do not conform to the requirements of the technical construction codes or other pertinent laws or ordinances, the city may not issue a permit, but shall return the contract documents to the applicant with refusal to issue such permit. Such refusal shall, when requested, be in writing and shall contain the reason for refusal. (c) Special foundation permit. When application for a permit to erect or enlarge a building has been filed and pending issuance of such permit the building official may, at his discretion, issue a special permit for the foundation only. The holder of such a special permit will be proceeding at his or her own risk and without assurance that a permit for the remainder of the work will be granted nor that corrections will not be required in order to meet provisions of the technical construction codes. (d) Public right-of-way. A permit shall not be authorized by the building official for the construction of any building, or for the alteration of any building where such building is to be changed and such change will affect the exterior walls, bays, balconies, or other appendages or projections fronting on any street, alley or public lane, or for the placing on any lot or premises of any building or structure removed from another lot or premises, unless the applicant presents to the city a plat or survey certified by a state-registered land surveyor, or other evidence acceptable to the city showing the location of applicable street rights-of-way and building setback lines; and it shall be the duty of the building official to see that the street lines are not encroached upon except as provided for in chapter 32 of the Georgia State Minimum Standard Building Code. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-54. - Contractors responsibilities. It shall be the duty of every contractor who shall make contracts for the installation or repairs of building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing systems, for which a permit is required, to comply with state or local rules and regulations concerning licensing, including a business license. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-55. - Conditions of the permit. (a) Permit intent. A permit issued shall be construed to be a license to proceed with the work and not as authority to violate, cancel, alter, or set aside any of the provisions of the technical construction codes, nor shall issuance of a permit prevent the building official from thereafter requiring a correction of errors in plans, construction, or violations of the technical construction codes. (b) Permit issued on basis of an affidavit. Whenever a permit is issued in reliance upon an affidavit or whenever the work to be covered by a permit involves installation under conditions which, in the opinion of the building official, are hazardous or complex, the building official shall require that the architect or engineer who signed the affidavit or prepared the drawings or computations shall supervise such work. In addition, they shall be responsible for conformity with the permit, provide copies of inspection reports as inspections are performed, and upon completion make and file with the building official written affidavit that the work has been done in conformity with the reviewed plans and with the structural provisions of the technical construction codes. In the event such architect or engineer is not available, the owner shall employ in his stead a competent person or agency whose qualifications are approved by the building official. (c) Plans. When the building official issues a permit, he shall endorse in writing or by stamp on all submitted plans "Reviewed for Code Compliance." One (1) set of drawings so reviewed shall be retained by the building official, one (1) set by the community development department and the remaining sets shall be returned to the applicant. The permitted drawings shall be kept at the site of work and shall be open to inspection by the building official or his authorized representative. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-56. - Fees. (a) Prescribed fees. A permit shall not be issued until the fees as prescribed by the mayor and council have been paid. Nor shall an amendment to a permit be released until the additional fee, if any, due to an increase in the estimated cost of the building, structure, electrical, plumbing, mechanical or gas systems, has been paid. (b) Working commencing before permit issuance. Any person who commences any work on a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system before obtaining the necessary permits, shall be subject to one hundred (100) percent of the usual permit fee in addition to the required permit fee. (c) Accounting. The building official shall keep a permanent and accurate accounting of all permit fees and other monies collected, the names of all persons upon whose account the same was paid, along with the date and amount thereof. (d) Schedule of permit fees. On all buildings, structures, electrical, plumbing, mechanical and gas systems or alterations requiring a permit, a fee for each permit shall be paid as required at the time of filing application, in accordance with the schedule of fees and charges maintained by the city clerk and established by the mayor and council. (e) Building permit valuation. If in the opinion of the building official, the valuation of the building, alteration, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing systems appears to be underestimated on the application, the permit shall be denied unless the applicant can show detailed estimates to meet the approval of the building official. Permits valuation shall include the total cost, such as electrical, gas, mechanical, plumbing equipment and other systems, including materials and labor. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-57. - Inspections. (a) Existing buildings inspections. Before issuing a permit, the building official may examine or cause to be examined any building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing systems for which an application has been received for a permit to enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish, install, or change the occupancy. He shall inspect all buildings, structures, electrical, gas, mechanical and plumbing systems, from time to time, during and upon completion of the work for which a permit was issued. He shall make a record of every such examination and inspection and of all violations of the technical construction codes. (b) Manufacturers and fabricators. When deemed necessary by the building official he shall make, or cause to be made, an inspection of materials or assemblies at the point of manufacture or fabrication. A record shall be made of every such examination and inspection and of all violations of the technical construction codes. (c) Inspection service. The building official may make, or cause to be made, the inspections required by this Code. He may accept reports of inspectors of recognized inspection services provided that after investigation he is satisfied as to their qualifications and reliability. A certificate called for by any provision of the technical construction codes shall not be based on such reports unless the same are in writing and certified by a responsible officer of such service. (d) Inspections prior to issuance of certificate of occupancy or completion. The building official shall inspect or cause to be inspected at various intervals all construction or work for which a permit is required and a final inspection shall be made of every building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system upon completion, prior to the issuance of the certificate of occupancy or completion. Site inspections and approvals shall be performed by the city and final approval shall be completed and received by the building official prior to the issuance of the certificate of occupancy or completion. (e) Posting of permit. Work requiring a permit shall not commence until the permit holder or his agent posts the permit card in a conspicuous place on the premises. The permit shall be protected from the weather and located in such position as to permit the building official or his representative to conveniently make the required entries thereon. This permit card shall be maintained in such position by the permit holder until the certificate of occupancy or completion is issued by the building official. The building permit shall be on the job site within ten (10) days after the permit is received and before any inspections are requested. The building permit shall contain the following text: "The issuance of this permit authorizes improvements of the real property designated herein which improvements may subject such property to mechanics' and materialmen's liens pursuant to Part 3 of Article 8 of Chapter 14 of Title 44 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. In order to protect any interest in such property and to avoid encumbrances thereon, the owner or any person with an interest in such property should consider contacting an attorney or purchasing a consumer's guide to the lien laws which may be available at building supply centers." (f) Required inspections. The building official upon notification from the permit holder or his agent shall make the following inspections and such other inspections as necessary, and shall either release that portion of the construction or shall notify the permit holder or his agent of any violations which must be corrected in order to comply with the technical construction codes. (1) Building. a. Footing/foundation inspection: To be made after trenches are excavated and forms erected. b. Slab inspection: To be made prior to the placing of concrete. c. Frame inspection: To be made after the roof, all framing, fireblocking and bracing is in place, all concealing wiring, all pipes, chimneys, ducts and vents are complete. d. Moisture barrier inspection: To be made prior to the installation of the exterior finishing materials. e. Final inspection: To be made after the building is completed and ready for occupancy. This will include a site inspection by the public works, water, sewer and zoning. (2) Electrical. a. Underground inspection: To be made after trenches or ditches are excavated, conduit or cable installed, and before any backfill is put in place. b. Rough-in inspection: To be made after the roof, framing, fireblocking and bracing is in place, and prior to the installation of wall or ceiling membranes. c. Meter set: To be made for temporary power prior to final occupancy of the building to allow for the starting up and testing of equipment. d. Final inspection: To be made after the building is complete, all required electrical fixtures are in place and properly connected, and the structure is ready for occupancy. (3) Plumbing. a. Underground inspection: To be made after trenches or ditches are excavated, piping installed, and before any backfill is put in place. This inspection shall require a pressure test on all underground sanitary drain lines. b. Rough-in inspection: To be made after the roof, framing, fireblocking and bracing is in place and all soil, waste and vent piping is complete and prior to the installation of wall or ceiling membranes. This inspection shall require a pressure test on all drain and water lines. c. Final inspection: To be made after the building is complete, all plumbing fixtures are in place and properly connected, and the structure is ready for occupancy. (4) Mechanical. a. Underground inspection: To be made after trenches or ditches are excavated, underground duct and fuel piping installed, and before any backfill is put in place. b. Rough-in inspection: To be made after the roof, framing, fireblocking and bracing are in place and all ducting, and other concealed components are complete, and prior to the installation of wall or ceiling membranes. c. Final inspection: To be made after the building is complete, the mechanical system is in place and properly connected, and the structure is ready for occupancy. (5) Gas. a. Rough piping inspection: To be made after all new piping authorized by the permit has been installed, and before any such piping has been covered or concealed or any fixtures or gas appliances have been connected. b. Meter set: To be made for temporary gas service prior to final occupancy of the building to allow for the starting up and testing of equipment. This inspection shall include a pressure test. c. Final piping inspection: To be made after all piping authorized by the permit has been installed and after all portions which are to be concealed by plastering or otherwise have been so concealed, and before any fixtures or gas appliances have been connected. This inspection shall include a pressure test. d. Final inspection: To be made on all new gas work authorized by the permit and such portions of existing systems as may be affected by new work or any changes, to insure compliance with all the requirements of this Code, and to assure that the installation and construction of the gas system is in accordance with reviewed plans. (6) Energy. a. Foundation inspection: Top be made before slab concrete s poured in place. To verify that perimeter insulation has been installed correctly on any slab on grade foundation, if required. b. Frame inspection: To be made before exterior wall insulation is concealed by wall board to check installation of exterior walls insulation and to inspect that all holes and cracks through the structure envelope have been sealed in an appropriate manner as to restrict air passage. c. Final inspection: To be made after the building in completed and ready for occupancy. To verify installation and R-value of ceiling and floor insulation. To verify correct SEER ratings on appliances. (g) Written release. Work shall not be done on any part of a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system beyond the point indicated in each successive inspection without first obtaining a written release from the building official. Such written release shall be given only after an inspection has been made of each successive step in the construction or installation as indicated by each of the foregoing inspections. (h) Reinforcing steel and structural frames. Reinforcing steel, structural frame, insulation, plumbing, or work of any part of any building or structure shall not be covered or concealed without first obtaining a release from the building official. (i) Plaster fire protection. In all buildings where plaster is used for fire protection purposes, the permit holder or his agent shall notify the building official after all lathing and backing is in place. Plaster shall not be applied until the release from the building official has been received. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-58. - Certificates of occupancy or completion. (a) Building occupancy. A new building shall not be occupied or a change made in the occupancy, nature or use of a building or part of a building until after the building official has issued a certificate of occupancy or completion. Such certificate shall not be issued until all required electrical, gas, mechanical, plumbing and fire protection systems have been inspected for compliance with the technical construction codes and other applicable laws and ordinances and released by the building official. (b) Issuing certificate of occupancy or completion. Upon satisfactory completion of construction of a building or structure and installation of electrical, gas, mechanical and plumbing systems in accordance with the technical construction codes, reviewed plans and specifications and after the final inspection, the building official shall issue a certificate of occupancy or completion stating the following: (1) Use and occupancy permitted; (2) Occupant load for each floor when limited by law; (3) Allowable load per square foot for each floor in accordance with the provisions of the technical construction codes (when applicable); (4) Building permit number; (5) Address of the building or structure; (6) Type of construction of the building or structure; (7) Statement of compliance with applicable codes; and (8) Any special stipulations or conditions of the building permit. (c) Temporary occupancy. A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued for a portion of a commercial building, which in the opinion of the building official, may be safely occupied prior to final completion of the building. The temporary certificate of occupancy shall be forfeited if the certificate of occupancy is not issued within ninety (90) days. (d) Existing building certificate of occupancy. A certificate of occupancy for any existing building may be obtained by applying to the building official and supplying the information and data necessary to determine compliance with the technical construction code for the occupancy intended. Where necessary, in the opinion of the building official, two (2) sets of detailed drawings or a general inspection or both may be required. When upon examination and inspection, it is found that the building conforms to the provision of the technical construction codes and other applicable law and ordinances for such occupancy, a certificate of occupancy shall be issued. (e) Certificate of completion. Upon satisfactory completing of a building, structure, electoral, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, a certificate of completion may be issued. This certificate is proof that a structure or system is complete and for certain types of permits is released for use and may be connected to a utility system. This certificate does not grant authority to occupy or connect a building, such as a shell building, prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-59. - Service utilities. (a) Connection of service utilities. No person shall make connections from a utility, source of energy, fuel, or power to any building or system which is regulated by the technical construction codes for which a permit is required, until released by the building official and a certificate of occupancy or completion is issued. (b) Temporary connection. The building official may authorize the temporary connection of the building or system to the utility source of energy, fuel, or power for the purpose of testing building service systems or for use under a temporary certificate of occupancy. (c) Authority to disconnect service utilities. The building official shall have the authority to authorize disconnection of utility service to the building, structure or system regulated by the technical construction codes, in case of emergency where necessary to eliminate an immediate hazard to life or property. The building official shall notify the serving utility, and whenever possible the owner and occupant of the building, structure or service system of the decision to disconnect prior to taking such action. If not notified prior to disconnecting, the owner or occupant of the building, structure or service system shall be notified in writing, as soon as practical thereafter. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-60. - Posting floor loads. (a) Occupancy. An existing or new building shall not be occupied for any purpose which will cause the floors thereof to be loaded beyond their safe capacity. The building official may permit occupancy of a building for mercantile, commercial or industrial purposes, by specific business, when he is satisfied that such capacity will not thereby be exceeded. (b) Storage and factory-industrial occupancies. It shall be the responsibility of the owner, agent, proprietor or occupant of Group A, Group S and Group F occupancies or any occupancy where excessive floor loading is likely to occur, to employ a competent architect or engineer in computing the safe load capacity. All such computations shall be accompanied by an affidavit from the architect or engineer stating the safe allowable floor load on each floor in pounds per square foot uniformly distributed. The computations and affidavit shall be filed as a permanent record of the building official. (c) Signs required. In every building or part of a building used for storage, industrial or hazardous purposes, the safe floor loads, as reviewed by the building official on the plan, shall be marked on plates or approved design which shall be supplied and securely affixed by the owner of the building in a conspicuous place in each story to which they relate. Such plates shall not be removed or defaced, and if lost, removed or defaced, shall be replaced by the owner of the building. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) ARTICLE VI. - TESTING
Sec. 5-61. - Tests. The building official may require tests or test reports as proof of compliance. Required tests are to be made at the expense of the owner, or his agent, by an approved testing laboratory or other approved agency. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Secs. 5-62—5-69. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - APPEALS
Sec. 5-70. - Appeals. (a) Decision of the building official. The owner of a building, structure or service system, or his duly authorized agent, may appeal a decision of the building official to the mayor and council whenever any one (1) of the following conditions are claimed to exist: (1) The building official rejected or refused to approve the mode or manner of construction proposed to be followed or materials to be used in the installation or alteration of a building, structure or service system. (2) The provisions of the building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing codes do not apply to this specific case. (3) That an equally good or more desirable form of installation can be employed in any specific case. (4) The true intent and meaning of the building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing codes or any of the regulations there under have been misconstrued or incorrectly interpreted. (b) Variances. The mayor and council, when so appealed to and after a hearing, may vary the application of any provision of the building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing codes to any particular case when, in its opinion after consulting with a professional engineer, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice and would be contrary to the spirit and purpose of the building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing codes or public interest, and also finds all of the following: (1) The special conditions and circumstances exist which are peculiar to the building, structure or service system involved and which are not applicable to others. (2) That the special conditions and circumstances do not result from the action or inaction of the applicant. (3) That granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is denied by the building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing codes to other buildings, structures or service system. (4) That the variance granted is the minimum variance that will make possible the reasonable use of the building, structure or service system. (5) That the grant of the variance will be in harmony with the general intent and purpose of the building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing codes and will not be detrimental to the public health, safety and general welfare. (c) Conditions of the variance. In granting the variance, the mayor and council may prescribe a reasonable time limit within which the action for which the variance is required shall be commenced or completed or both. In addition, the mayor and council may prescribe appropriate conditions and safeguards in conformity with the building, electrical, gas, mechanical and plumbing codes. Violation of the conditions of a variance shall be deemed a violation of these codes. (d) Notice of appeal. Notice of appeal shall be in writing and filed within thirty (30) calendar days after the decision is rendered by the building official. Appeals shall be in a form acceptable to the building official. The written notice of appeal shall be filed with the city clerk's office. (e) Unsafe or dangerous buildings or service systems. In the case of a building, structure or service system which, in the opinion of the building official, is unsafe, unsanitary or dangerous, the building official may, in his order, limit the time for such appeals to a shorter period. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-71. - Decisions. The mayor and council shall, in each case, reach a decision without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. Each decision shall also include the reasons for the decision. If decision reverses or modifies a refusal, order, or disallowance of the building official or varies the application of any provision of the building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing codes, the building official shall immediately take action in accordance with such decision. Every decision shall be promptly filed in writing in the permit office and the office of the building official and shall be open to public inspection. A certified copy of the decision shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant and a copy shall be kept publicly posted in the permit office and the office of the building official for two (2) weeks after the filing. Every decision of the mayor and council shall be final subject to any such remedy as any aggrieved party might have at law or in equity. All decisions and records of the mayor and council shall be available under the Open Records Act as required by the State of Georgia from the city clerk. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Secs. 5-72—5-79. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES
Sec. 5-80. - Advertising. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation who is not an electrical, mechanical, or plumbing contractor duly licensed by Georgia State Construction Industry Board to display a sign stating or implying that he or she is conducting a business of an electrical, conditioned air or plumbing contractor within the city, to claim orally that such is the case or to advertise by use of a business card, stationery, publication, or any other means that he or she or they are operating a contracting business in the city. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-81. - Penalty. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or agent to violate a provision of the technical construction codes or this chapter, or fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, or to erect, construct, alter, install, demolish or move any structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system in violation of a detailed statement or drawing submitted and permitted under the technical construction codes or this chapter. Each such person shall be considered guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of the technical construction codes or this chapter is committed or continued, and upon conviction of any such violation such person shall be punished within the limits and as provided by ordinance or charter of the city. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Secs. 5-82—5-89. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - MISCELLANEOUS
Sec. 5-90. - Liability. Any officer or employee, or member of the construction board of adjustment and appeals, charged with the enforcement of the technical construction codes, acting for the city in the discharge of his/her duties, shall not thereby render himself/herself personally liable, and is hereby relieved from all personal liability, for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his/her duties. Any suit brought against any officer or employee or board member because of such act performed by him/her in the enforcement of any provision of the technical construction codes shall be defended by the city attorney until the final termination of the proceedings. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Secs. 5-91—5-99. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - EXCAVATING AND TRENCHING
Sec. 5-100. - Definitions For the purpose of this article, the following words shall have the following meanings: (a) Certificate means the certificate issued by the city upon satisfactory completion of a mandatory training/educational program regarding excavation and trench safety practices, such program to be provided by either the city or the county. (b) Certificate-holder means the holder of the certificate identified in the above definition. (c) Excavation means any manmade cavity or depression in the earth's surface, including its sides, walls, or faces, formed by earth removal and producing unsupported earth conditions by reasons of the excavation. If installed forms or similar structures reduce the depth-to-width relationship, an excavation may become a trench. (d) OSHA means the U.S. Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration, or successor agency. (e) Supervisory personnel means any person who has the responsibility for layout, oversight, superintending, directing, or controlling an excavation or trenching site. (f) Trench is a narrow excavation made below the surface of the ground. In general, the depth is greater than the width, but the width of a trench is not greater than fifteen (15) feet. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-101. - Prohibition. No individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity of any kind whatsoever shall engage in any excavation or trenching except in compliance with the provisions of this article and in compliance with any applicable laws of the state or of the United States or any rules and regulations of OSHA, or any other state or federal governmental entity or department promulgating rules and regulations applicable to excavating and trenching. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-102. - Adoption of OSHA safety and health regulations. All safety and health regulations adopted by OSHA with regard to excavating and trenching operations, particularly Part 1926, Subpart P- Excavations, Trenching, and Shoring, Section 1926.650, 1926.651, 1926.652, 1926.653 of the Code of Federal Regulations, as the same now exist or may be hereafter amended, are adopted as a part of this article the same as if quoted verbatim herein. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-103. - Certificate required. (a) No equipment operator or supervisory personnel shall participate in any excavation or trenching or in any way work in an excavation or trench unless such person holds a valid certificate from the city evidencing satisfactory completion of a required educational program on safe trench/excavation practices as may be required. No other person shall participate in or work in any excavation or trenching site unless a certificate-holder is present at the excavation or trench site where work is being performed. (b) In the event any person who holds a valid certificate is found to be in violation of the safety standards and requirements on any jobsite, the certificate may be revoked after notice and hearing as herein provided. In the event of revocation, the certificate may be reinstated one (1) time upon repeat by the person of the educational program required for issuance of the initial certificate. (c) No certificate shall be suspended or revoked, except for due cause, and after a hearing before the mayor and council upon written notice to the holder of such certificate of the time, place and purpose of such a hearing and a statement of the charge upon which such hearing shall be held. Three (3) days' notice shall be deemed reasonable, but shorter or longer periods of notice shall be authorized as the mayor and council may deem the circumstances justify. Due cause for revocation shall consist of the violating of any laws or ordinances regulating excavating or trenching. At any such hearing, the certificate-holder shall be entitled to be represented by an attorney and to cross-examine any witnesses who may appear and to present evidence in his own behalf. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-104. - Permit required. No excavating or trenching shall be performed until a permit or authorization for same has been obtained from the city. Any applicant will be required to acknowledge receipt and understanding of safety requirements before any permit will be issued. All such permits shall be conspicuously posted upon the jobsite. No such permit shall be suspended or revoked except for due cause and after hearing before the mayor and council after notice to the permit holder of the date, time and place of hearing, along with notice of the charges. Due cause shall consist of the violating of any laws or ordinances regulating excavating or trenching. Three (3) days' notice shall be deemed reasonable, but shorter or longer periods of notice shall be authorized as the mayor and council may deem the circumstances to justify. At such hearing, the permit-holder shall be entitled to be represented by an attorney, to cross-examine any witnesses who may appear against him, and to present evidence in his own behalf. No permit or authorization shall be issued unless an authorized agent of the applicant holds a certificate. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-105. - Inspection by city. City personnel shall periodically inspect trench/excavation sites. Such inspectors shall, among other things, verify the presence of the required permit, verify existence of required certificates, and verify compliance to OSHA safety standards adopted in section 5-102. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 ) Sec. 5-106. - Violations. (a) Violations of this article may result in revocation or suspension of any certificate or permit issued hereunder as hereinabove set out. (b) A notice of violation shall be issued for any deficiency. Upon receipt of such notice, the deficiency shall be corrected immediately. (c) All excavation and trenching work upon any jobsite shall cease immediately when there is trench activity by any person not a certificate-holder and/or when the deficiencies cannot be corrected immediately and/or when there is a refusal or failure to correct immediately and/or when such work is being done without a permit. (d) If deficiencies identified in a notice of violation are not corrected, the building permit, land disturbance permit or any other permit issued by the city may be suspended or revoked for due cause upon the conditions herein identified for revocation of permit. (e) Flagrant and/or repeated violations shall be reported by the city to OSHA for action by that agency. (f) Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or entity of any kind whatsoever violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or six (6) months' imprisonment or both for each violation. (g) In addition, every violation of the terms of this article by any person, firm, partnership, corporation or entity of any kind whatsoever shall be deemed a nuisance and a continuing nuisance so long as such violation may be continued; and such violation is subject to abatement as a nuisance as provided by the laws of this state. (h) Any violation of this article shall be subject to injunction. (i) The above remedies are cumulative. Pursuance of any one (1) remedy shall not be deemed an election of remedies and shall not prohibit pursuance of more than one (1) remedy simultaneously. ( Ord. No. 2014-004, § 1(Exh. A), 4-7-14 )

div.head: Chapter 6 - COURT AND CRIMINAL PROCEDURE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Municipal court, § 4.10 et seq.
Sec. 6-1. - Types of bail. All persons charged with a violation of a provision of this Code or other city ordinance are entitled to be released in accordance with their qualification in one (1) of the following categories: (1) Copy of charges. All bona fide citizens of the city or county are entitled to release on copy of charges provided the violation is the first violation and the cash bond would not exceed sixty dollars ($60.00). (2) Posting cash bond. All persons charged with a violation of a provision of this Code or other city ordinance will be permitted to post a cash bond in the amount specified in the cash bond schedule. (3) Signed bonds. Any taxpayer of the city or county may sign a bond in an amount of twice the cash bond schedule, for themselves or anyone of their choice, provided, that only one (1) bond shall be outstanding at any time. Current tax receipt, with copy of deed to property to be pledged, will provide sufficient proof of ownership. (4) Security bonds. Any licensed professional bondsman, or such bondsman's employee of record, may sign a bond in an amount of twice the cash bond schedule, provided, said bondsman maintains such business in accordance with professional bonding regulations of this Code, if any. (Ord. of 9-3-73, §§ 1—4) Sec. 6-2. - Bond as security; failure to appear; forfeiture of bond. When police officers have made arrest of any offender against any provision of the Code or other city ordinance, and where a bond is required and a trial cannot be had immediately, the officer may take bond and security for the defendant's appearance before the municipal judge, or if such person fails or refuses to give such bond, the officer may confine such offender in the city jail until a trial can be held. When a bond is taken and the offender shall fail to appear at the time appointed, the municipal judge shall forfeit such bond and issue a rule against such defendant on a day to be named, or in default thereof, that judgment be entered against the defendant and such securities. (Code 1972, § 6-202) Sec. 6-3. - Cash bond as security in arrests for failure to have insurance under the Georgia Motor Vehicle Accident Reparations Act. When police officers have made arrest of any offender for failure to show proof of automobile insurance as required by the Georgia Motor Vehicle Accident Reparations Act, the officer may take a cash bond and security in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the offender's appearance before the municipal judge. The municipal judge shall proceed in the same manner as authorized under section 6-2 upon the failure of the offender to appear at the time appointed. (Code 1972, § 6-209) State Law reference— Georgia Motor Vehicle Accident Reparations Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-1 et seq. Sec. 6-4. - Appearance before recorder; contempt of court. In any case where any person is charged with any violation of the provisions of this Code or other ordinance and has been given a copy of charges requiring such person to appear before the municipal judge, at a specified time and place, it shall be such person's duty to appear as specified. Any person failing to appear at the time and place set out in such charges or citations shall be guilty of contempt of court and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished for same. (Code 1972, § 6-204) Sec. 6-5. - Attendance of witnesses. The attendance of witnesses may be enforced by subpoena under the same rules as in superior court, and any witness who shall fail to attend the municipal court after having been legally subpoenaed or who shall refuse to testify shall be punished as for contempt of court. (Code 1972, § 6-206) Sec. 6-6. - Collection of fines. When a fine has been imposed by the municipal judge, the offender shall be held in the city jail until it has been paid or a satisfactory manner agreed upon by which it can be collected. (Code 1972, § 6-207) Editor's note— A schedule of fines for violation of city ordinances was adopted by an ordinance of April 4, 1977. That ordinance is not included in this Code, but copies are maintained on file in the police department and in the office of the city clerk, where they are available for public inspection. Ord. No. 91-2, § 1, adopted Jan. 7, 1991, increased the fines by 15%. Sec. 6-7. - Court costs. Court costs shall be determined under the provisions of section 4.13 of the City Charter. All court fines shall have added a surcharge of seven (7) percent to be paid into a special jail fund to be used to defray the costs to the city which are associated with the incarceration of municipal prisoners. (Code 1972, § 6-208; Ord. No. 2016-017 , § 1, 7-18-16) Sec. 6-8. - Appeal. In any case where a person is convicted of a violation of the provision of this Code or other ordinance and is not satisfied with the decision, such person may appeal under the provisions of section 4.14 of the city charter. (Code 1972, § 6-205) Sec. 6-9. - Appointment of chief judge and stand-by judge of municipal court. (a) The council shall appoint by resolution a person the council considers qualified to serve as chief judge, who shall preside over the municipal court of the city. Such appointment shall become effective immediately; and the appointee shall serve until he resigns, is replaced, or otherwise becomes unable to serve. (b) In the event the presiding judge of the municipal court of the city is unable at any time to serve in his official capacity, the council shall appoint by resolution such other person the council considers qualified to replace such judge; and as a precaution against a possible interim vacancy in the judgeship of the court, the council shall provide by resolution a standby judge, which person shall be immediately empowered to act as judge of the court at the notification of the council and continue until further resolution by the council. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the council in its discretion may appoint one of more other judges to preside over all or certain kinds of cases in the interest of efficient operation of the court. Any such appointment shall serve until he or she resigns, is replaced, otherwise becomes unable to serve, or in the event the council decides that such judgeship is no longer needed. (Ord. No. 88-7, 2-15-88; Ord. No. 2009-060, § 1, 12-7-09) Editor's note— Ord. No. 88-7, adopted Feb. 15, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion as § 6-9 was at the discretion of the editor. Sec. 6-10. - City solicitor for municipal court. (a) There shall be one or more city solicitors for the municipal court of the city, who shall be the prosecuting attorneys for the city for all cases in the municipal court for the city. If there are multiple solicitors, the council shall have the discretion in its appointment to specify the types of cases which will be prosecuted by the appointed solicitor, or it may make a general appointment in which the appointed solicitor may prosecute all kinds of cases within the jurisdiction of the municipal court. (b) In order to be qualified for the position of city solicitor, such a person shall be at least twenty-five (25) years of age and shall have been admitted to practice law within the state prior to appointment to solicitor. (c) The council shall appoint by resolution one or more persons duly qualified to serve as city solicitors. Such appointment shall become effective immediately; and the appointee shall serve until he resigns, is replaced, otherwise becomes unable to serve, or the council decides such position is no longer needed. (d) Compensation for the city solicitor shall be from city funds as provided by the council by resolution. (e) The city solicitor shall be a part-time solicitor and may engage in the private practice of law but may not practice in his own court or appear in any matter as to which that solicitor has exercised jurisdiction. (f) In the event of a vacancy in the office of city solicitor, the council shall appoint a qualified person to fill the vacancy. This person shall continue to serve until he resigns, is replaced, otherwise becomes unable to serve, or the council decides such position is no longer needed. (Ord. No. 88-15, 7-5-88; Ord. No. 2009-060, § 1, 12-7-09) Editor's note— Ord. No. 88-15, adopted July 5, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion as § 6-10 was at the discretion of the editor.

div.head: Chapter 7 - ELECTIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Elections, § 5.10 et seq.
Sec. 7-1. - Authority for county to conduct municipal elections. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 21-2-45(c), the city does hereby authorize the county to conduct elections held pursuant to the Georgia Election Code (O.C.G.A. § 21-2-1 et seq.) and authorizes the county to perform all duties as superintendent of elections as specified under O.C.G.A. Tit. 21, Ch. 3. (Code 1972, § 3-301; Ord. No. 2007-06, 5-21-07; Ord. No. 2009-001, 1-5-09) State Law reference— Duties of superintendent, managers and clerks, O.C.G.A. Tit. 21, Ch. 2. Sec. 7-1.1. - Election officials. The mayor and council shall by resolution either appoint the county to perform all duties as superintendent of elections pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 21-2-45(c)(1) or appoint a municipal election superintendent, election managers, registrars, absentee ballot clerk and any other officials as are necessary, all of whom shall exercise those powers and duties set forth in the Georgia Election Code (O.C.G.A. § 21-2-1 et seq.). (Ord. No. 2007-06, 5-21-07) Sec. 7-2. - Expenses. The election superintendent is authorized to incur expenses in the preparation and conduct of an election including the cost of purchasing identification badges for poll officers, the printing of ballots and voters' certificates, and the purchasing of all other supplies necessary for the conduct of an election, except where such supplies are provided by the state. The superintendent is further authorized to incur all necessary expenses to provide voting booths for the proper conduct of all elections. (Code 1972, § 3-302; Ord. No. 2007-06, 5-21-07) State Law reference— Funding of elections required, O.C.G.A. Tit. 21, Ch. 2. Sec. 7-3. - Election districts and polling places. (a) The city shall be divided into three (3) election districts or precincts, as now or hereafter described in the City Charter; those electors living within their respective election districts or precincts shall vote at such polling places as shall be designated by the governing authority as provided by law. The elections superintendent shall cause all polling places to be provided with sufficient light and heat. (b) Polling places for city elections fo Powder Springs are hereby established as: (1) Ward 1: George E. Ford Center, 4818 Atlanta Street, Powder Springs, GA, 30127. (2) Ward 2: Ron Anderson Building, 3820 Macedonia Road, Powder Springs, GA, 30127. (3) Ward 3: First Baptist Church of Powder Springs, 4330 North Avenue, Powder Springs, GA, 30127. (Code 1972, § 3-303; Ord. No. 93-12, §§ 1, 2, 6-7-93; Ord. No. 93-21, § 1, 8-2-93; Ord. No. 2005-15, § 1, 6-6-05; Ord. No. 2007-06, 5-21-07; Ord. No. 2007-10, 6-18-07) Charter reference— Election districts, § 5.11. State Law reference— Election districts and polling places, O.C.G.A. Tit. 21, Ch. 2. Sec. 7-4. - Registrars. The governing body shall appoint registrars, as necessary, who shall serve at the pleasure of the governing body and who shall receive such compensation as provided by the governing body. The registrar shall exercise those powers and duties set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code [O.C.G.A. § 21-2-1 et seq.] The registrar shall provide a list of electors to the chief manager of each election district for each election. (Code 1972, § 3-305) State Law reference— Appointment of registrars, O.C.G.A. Tit. 21, Ch. 2. Sec. 7-5. - Registration of electors; challenge. (a) The city hereby elects to use the county registration list for the registration of electors. Persons desiring to vote in city elections shall register with the county registrar no later than 5:00 p.m. on the day thirty (30) days prior to the date of the election in the case of a general election of five (5) days prior to the date of a special election. The applicant must appear in person before the registrar and must have been a resident of the municipality prior to any municipal election in which such person votes. The procedure and form of registration shall conform to the Georgia Election Code [O.C.G.A. § 21-2-1 et seq.] (b) Any elector of the municipality shall be allowed to challenge the right of registration of any person whose name appears upon the elector list or who is applying for registration with the registrar. Any such challenge shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 21-2-229 et seq. (Code 1972, § 3-304; Ord. No. 2007-06, 5-21-07) State Law reference— Voter registration, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-120 et seq. Sec. 7-5.1. - Nomination of candidates. (a) Except as otherwise provided by state law, all candidates for municipal office shall file their notice of candidacy and pay the prescribed qualifying fee by the date prescribed in order to be eligible to have their names placed on the election ballot by the election superintendent in the following manner: Each candidate for municipal office or a designee shall file a notice of candidacy in the office of the election superintendent during the city's qualifying period. The city council shall designate the days of the qualifying period, which shall be no less than three (3) days and no more than five (5) days. The days of the qualifying period shall be consecutive days. Qualifying periods shall commence no earlier than 8:30 a.m. on the last Monday in August immediately preceding the general election and shall end no later than 4:30 p.m. on the following Friday; and, in the case of a special election, the municipal qualifying period shall commence no earlier than the date of the call and shall end no later than twenty-five (25) days prior to the election. (b) The hours of qualifying each day shall be from 8:30 a.m. until 4:30 p.m. with one hour allowed for the lunch break; provided, however, that should the city have normal business hours. Except in the case of a special election, notice of the opening and closing dates and the hours for candidates to qualify shall be published at least two (2) weeks prior to the opening of the qualifying period. (c) No person shall be eligible to serve as mayor or councilmember unless he or she shall have been a resident of the city for a period of twelve (12) months immediately prior to the date qualifying; and the mayor or councilmember shall continue to reside therein during his or her period of service and to be registered and qualified to vote in municipal elections of this city. (Code 1972, § 3-306; Ord. No. 2007-06, 5-21-07) Editor's note— The provision of § 3-306 of the 1972 Code were inadvertently omitted at time of codification of this 1987 Code. The editor has included the provisions as § 7-5.1. State Law reference— Nomination of candidates, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-91(a)(1); candidates seeking one of two or more public offices, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-93. Sec. 7-6. - Fixing qualification fees. The governing body shall fix and publish a qualification fee, to be paid by candidates seeking election in a special or general election, at least two (2) weeks prior to the closing of qualifications. The fee shall be paid to the municipal election superintendent at the time a candidate files notice of candidacy. Said fee shall not exceed three (3) percent of the annual compensation of the office. (Code 1972, § 3-307; Ord. No. 2007-06, 5-21-07) State Law reference— Fixing qualification fee, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-90. Sec. 7-7. - Absentee ballots. Absentee ballots may be used in all municipal elections. The use of absentee ballots shall be governed by O.C.G.A. §§ 21-2-380 through 21-2-390. (Code 1972, § 3-308; Ord. No. 2007-06, 5-21-07) Sec. 7-8. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 2007-06, adopted May 21, 2007, repealed § 7-8, in its entirety. Former § 7-8 pertained to contested elections and derived from Code 1972, § 3-309. Sec. 7-9. - Maintenance of voter registration list by county. The city authorizes the county to maintain the city voter registration list. (Ord. No. 91-16, 1-3-91) Editor's note— Ord. No. 91-16, adopted Jan. 3, 1991, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion as § 7-9 was at the discretion of the editor.

div.head: Chapter 7.5 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Civil emergencies, Ch. 19.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 7.5-1—7.5-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 97-6, adopted Apr. 7, 1997, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion of the substantive provisions of such ordinance as Ch. 7.5, Art. II, §§ 7.5-31—7.5-33, was at the discretion of the editor.
Sec. 7.5-31. - Definitions. [The following words, terms or phrases, as used in this article, shall have their given meanings:] Alarm system. Any assembly of equipment, mechanical, electrical or battery-operated, arranged to signal the occurrence of a police, fire, hazard or medical emergency requiring immediate attention and to which police or fire units are expected to respond. False alarm. (1) An alarm activated in the absence of an emergency, whether willfully or by inadvertence, negligence or unintentional act, including the malfunction of the alarm system, to which the police department responds. The definition excludes testing or repairing of telephone or electrical lines or equipment outside the premises; acts of God, such as earthquake, flood, windstorm, thunder or lightning; an attempted illegal entry of which there is visible evidence; a crime in progress; or, in the case of an emergency medical alarm, an actual medical emergency requiring police, fire and/or medical personnel. If doubt exists as to the cause of the false alarm, the chief of police or his designee shall have and make the final decision regarding the circumstances of the activation. (2) Multiple alarms received by the police department before the system can be deactivated within a reasonable period of time shall be considered a single alarm. (3) The definition of a false alarm also includes the intentional activation of a holdup alarm for other than a holdup in progress, the intentional activation of a burglary alarm for other than a burglary, the activation of a medical alarm for other than a medical emergency, or the intentional activation of a fire alarm for other than a fire or hazard. Police department. The Powder Springs Police Department. Police emergency. An incident requiring prompt response by the police department. (Ord. No. 97-6, 4-7-97) Sec. 7.5-32. - False alarms prohibited. The owner of the property at which an alarm system is installed, and the owner or operator of the alarm system (if not the owner of the property), shall insure that his/her alarm system is functioning properly and that shall not cause false alarms to be transmitted. Any police officer responding to an alarm which is determined to be false shall promptly notify the chief of police or his designee of such alarm in writing, and (if practical) leave notification of such false alarm at the scene of the alarm. (Ord. No. 97-6, 4-7-97) Sec. 7.5-33. - Penalties for false alarms. (a) First and second false alarms/activation per calendar month: Warning. (b) Third false alarm/activation per calendar month: Fifty-dollar ($50.00) fine. (c) Fourth and subsequent false alarm/activation per calendar month: One hundred-dollar ($100.00) fine per alarm. (d) Penalties provided for false alarms that are relayed or transmitted by an intermediary shall be the responsibility of the owner or user of the alarm system. (e) Any person found guilty of willful, false activation of alarm system shall be liable for a fine up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) plus the cost of prosecution or to imprisonment in the county prison for a term not to exceed thirty (30) days, or both, for each and every such activation. (Ord. No. 97-6, 4-7-97)

div.head: Chapter 8 - FINANCE AND TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Fiscal administration, §§ 2.30, 6.10 et seq. Cross reference— Clerk to keep books of account, disburse funds, etc., § 2-43; occupational license taxes, Ch. 12.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Note— See the editor's note to Art. II of this chapter, § 8-30 et seq.
Sec. 8-01. - Financial director. (a) Authority: The council has the authority to hire a financial director who shall act as the chief fiscal advisor to the city manager, and direct all activities relating to financial planning, accounting, revenue administration, and treasury management; and whose job description is given in the subsequent subsections of this section. (b) Duties Generally: The financial director is responsible for serving as the chief fiscal advisor to the city manager. He is to supervise and coordinate the work of several subordinates in the following areas: accounting, finances, taxes, business licenses, data operations and utility billing. The financial director will also supervise the following: accounts receivable clerk, permits clerk, and data entry clerk. The work is to be performed under the general direction of the city manager. (c) Examples of Work: The following examples are illustrative of the duties assigned to this classification. No attempt is made to be exhaustive in this listing. (1) Under the general direction of the city manager, oversees financial operations for all city services. a. Plans, reviews, supervises and instructs the work of subordinates engaged in accounting, data processing, business licensing, tax and utility billing, etc. b. Evaluates performance of subordinates and administers personnel functions in accordance with all applicable personnel policies and procedures. (2) Advises the city manager on all financial matters. a. Supervises and directs the preparation and maintenance of regular and special accounting records and financial statements and reports. b. Interprets data. (3) Develops, installs and maintains accounting and budgetary systems which provide control of expenditures within all applicable guidelines, rules, regulations, legal constraints and budgetary controls. a. Recommends changes in fiscal policy regulations and procedures as necessary. b. Reviews and advises on an in-house computer system for maximum efficiency and effectiveness. c. Directs and ensures the accurate collection, recording and reporting of all utility revenues, taxes, business license fees, etc., collected by the city. d. Reviews and advises on ordinances and resolutions relating to expenditures, revenues, bonds and other fiscal matters. e. Invests municipal funds and closely monitors outstanding investments to obtain optimum return for the city. f. Directs and participates, in conjunction with independent auditors, in annual audit of all municipal financial transactions. (4) Prepares revenue estimates and/or forecasts for annual budget. a. Assists the city manager in the development and presentation of the annual budget. b. Compiles data for both operating and capital improvement budgets. c. Assists the city manager, mayor and council in analyzing and reviewing budgetary requests. (5) Confers with the public on matters relating to city finances and collections and interprets, explains and/or clarifies financial policies, objectives and requirements. (6) Performs other related duties as assigned. (d) Desirable Knowledge, Skills and Abilities: (1) Knowledge of: a. Generally accepted accounting principles and procedures. b. Principals of public finance administration and governmental accounting standards. c. Effective budgetary principles and practices. d. Effective investment strategies. e. Municipal Code of Ordinances. f. Mainframe and personal computer operations an applications. g. Standard office and accounting equipment. (2) Skill in: a. Managerial and supervisory practices. b. Effective oral and written communication. c. Training and motivating subordinates. (3) Ability to: a. Analyze complex financial data and prepare conclusions and recommendations based upon analyses. b. Exercise sound judgment. c. Assess financial constraints and react accordingly. d. Communicate ideas effectively. e. Speak and write clearly and concisely. f. Plan, organize and direct the work of others. g. Establish and maintain effective working relationships with other department heads, public officials, etc. (e) Minimum Education and Experience Requirements: The following standards express the minimum background of training and experience required to qualify for this classification. Other training or experience, if evaluated as equivalent, may qualify an applicant for a position within this class. (1) Completion of a bachelor's degree in accounting, finance or business administration with emphasis in accounting or finance. (2) Three (3) to five (5) years' progressively responsible professional experience in accounting and/or fiscal management, preferably including supervisory responsibilities. Experience in governmental accounting or fiscal management is desirable. In lieu of a degree, experience as described above may be substituted on a year-to-year basis. (Ord. No. 88-26, 9-6-88) Editor's note— Ord. No. 88-26, adopted Sept. 6, 1988, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion as § 8-01 was at the discretion of the editor. See also §§ 8-16, 8-17, 8-19. Charter reference— Authority, § 3.10 et seq. Sec. 8-1. - Fiscal year. The city shall operate on a fiscal year which shall begin on the first day of July and end on the thirtieth day of June. (Code 1972, § 3-501) State Law reference— Establishing fiscal year, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-3. Sec. 8-2. - Signing of contracts, deeds, bonds. The mayor shall sign and execute all contracts authorized by the governing body. The mayor shall also be authorized to sign the deeds and bonds of the city. (Code 1972, § 2-402) Sec. 8-3. - Temporary loans. The city manager may obtain short-term loans in the name of the city when approved by the governing body. Any such indebtedness shall be payable solely from the proceeds of a duly authorized bond issue or from a specific designated source, unless there is a prior appropriation out of which such indebtedness could be paid. (Code 1972, § 2-403) Sec. 8-4. - Proposed budget. (a) The city manager shall, on or before the fifteenth day of May each year; submit to the governing body a proposed budget for the following fiscal year showing the anticipated receipts and the proposed expenditures by fund and the reason for the expenditures, as well as all other budget requirements of the city charter. (b) The various department heads shall on or before the fifteenth day of April each year submit to the city manager a budget request for their respective departments for the following fiscal year. (Code 1972, § 3-502) State Law reference— Adoption of budget, O.C.G.A. § 36-81-3 et seq. Sec. 8-5. - Financial statement. The governing body shall cause to be published within six (6) months after the close of each fiscal year in accordance with state law a general balance sheet and statement of revenues and expenditures showing all municipal accounts as of the close of such preceding fiscal year. (Code 1972, § 3-504) Sec. 8-6. - Fingerprinting cost. A five-dollar fee shall be assessed each individual fingerprinted by the police department at such individual's request. (Ord. No. 83-1, 1-3-83) Sec. 8-7. - Funds for purchase of mortgages by housing authority. The housing authority of Cobb County is authorized to make available such funds as it desires for purchase of mortgages of single-family residential units located within the city, and the city does hereby consent to such program of the authority. (Ord. No. 82-11, 8-16-82) Sec. 8-8. - Ad valorem taxes. In accordance with sections 6.11 and 6.26 of the City Charter, upon adoption of the current fiscal budget, the mayor and city council shall, by ordinance, establish a millage rate for the city property tax on all property subject to same. The mayor and city council, by ordinance, shall also determine the date when payment for ad valorem taxes shall be due and whether said payment shall be made in one lump sum or by installments spread out over a period of time. Prior to adoption of the millage rate, the mayor and city council shall direct that a report be published in a newspaper of general circulation throughout the county for at least two (2) weeks prior to the adoption of the above-referenced millage rates stating the following: (1) The assessed taxable value of all property, by class and in total, which is within the levying authority's taxing jurisdiction and the proposed millage rate for the levying authority's purposes for the current calendar year and such assessed taxable values and the millage rates for each of the immediately preceding five (5) calendar years, as well as the proposed total dollar amount of ad valorem taxes to be levied for the levying authority's purposes for the current calendar year and the total dollar amount of ad valorem taxes levied for the levying authority's purposes for each of the immediately preceding five (5) calendar years. The information required for each year specified in this paragraph shall also indicate the percentage increase and total dollar increase with respect to the immediately preceding calendar year. In the event the rate levied in the unincorporated area is different from the rate levied in the incorporated area, the report shall also indicate all required information with respect to the incorporated area, unincorporated area, and a combination of incorporated and unincorporated areas; and (2) The date, time, and place where the mayor and city council will be setting its millage rate. (Code 1972, § 3-402; Ord. No. 2003-24, § 1, 8-18-03) Sec. 8-9. - Same—Levy for payment of general obligation bonds. There is hereby set and levied for the payment of principal and interest on general obligation bonds an annual ad valorem tax as prescribed by the governing body upon all real and personal property within the city. This tax shall become due, and notice of this tax shall be given, in the same manner as provided in section 8-8. A statement of this levy shall be shown separately on tax collection bills. (Code 1972, § 3-406; Ord. No. 2003-24, § 2, 8-18-03) Sec. 8-10. - Same—Assessments of fair market value. In determining the fair market value of real and personal property subject to the city's taxing authority, the city shall accept the assessments made by the county board of tax assessors as fair and accurate. (Code 1972, § 3-403; Ord. No. 2003-24, § 3, 8-18-03) State Law reference— Use of county valuation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-352. Sec. 8-11. - Same—Appeals of fair market value assessments. All appeals by dissatisfied property owners which result from an assessment made by the county shall be made to the county board of tax assessors in the manner specified by said board. (Code 1972, § 3-404; Ord. No. 2003-24, § 4, 8-18-03) Sec. 8-12. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 2003-34, §§ 3—5, adopted Aug. 18, 2003, amended §§ 8-10—8-12. Former § 8-10 was deleted and §§ 8-11 and 8-12 were renumbered as §§ 8-10 and 8-11, to read as set out herein. Sec. 8-13. - Reserved. Editor's note— Section 8-13, relating to collection of taxes, derived from Code 1972, § 3-405, was repealed by § 2 of Ord. No. 91-3, adopted Jan. 21, 1991. See now § 8-15 et seq. Sec. 8-14. - Conditions to city fund expenditures. (a) It shall be the policy of the city that funds used for city expenditures be authorized in accordance with the following conditions: (1) Expenditure less than five thousand dollars: If the item is included in the current year budget, the city manager is authorized to negotiate the purchase or request bids at his discretion and approval. Provided, however, that any and all contracts or expenditures for legal, audit or engineering services are excepted from any requirement of solicitation or acceptance of bids. (2) Expenditure more than five thousand dollars: If the item is included in the current year budget, the city manager is required to receive bids before a purchase can be approved. The mayor and council will review and select a vendor/contractor from among the bids. Provided, however, that any and all contracts or expenditures for legal, audit, engineering or other professional services are excepted from any requirement of solicitation or acceptance of bids. (3) Nonbudget items: If the item is not included in the current year budget, the city manager must first receive approval of a budget revision from the mayor and council prior to any expenditure. Depending upon the amount, either condition (1) or (2) above will apply. (4) Emergency situation: If an emergency situation exists, the city manager is authorized to obtain equipment or service as necessary. As soon as practical afterwards, the mayor and council will be fully informed and approve the expenditures. (5) Definition of emergency: An emergency shall be defined for purposes of this section as a situation requiring the purchase and immediate use of a service or product without which the health, safety and welfare of employees or citizens could be seriously jeopardized. Examples of such products or service include the following: a. Pumping of sewerage to prevent effluent from entering streams or waterways. b. Emergency repairs to a generator required for maintenance of public services. c. Emergency work performed by water/sewer contractors to correct major water line blow-out. After such purchase, the city manager shall immediately notify the mayor and council on the reason and amount of the purchase. (b) If it can be reasonably determined by the finance officer that a product or service may be obtained at the lowest price through the state bid process or the county purchasing agreement, then the requirement for city bidding need not apply. After such product or service is obtained through either the state bid process or the county purchasing agreement, the city manager should notify the mayor and council in writing as soon as possible. (c) Federally assisted programs. (1) Notwithstanding any provision of this article, the purchase of equipment, supplies and/or services involving the expenditure of Community Development Block Grant (CDBG), HOME, or any other funds originating with the U. S. Department of Housing and Urban Development shall follow federal requirements in accordance with 24 CFR Part 85, as applicable. (2) The purchasing manager, city manager, or designee shall ensure that the purchase of equipment, supplies and/or services involving the expenditure of funds originating with the federal government shall comply with federal requirements associated with the program under which such funds are provided. (3) All procurement transactions involving federal financial assistance will be conducted in a manner providing full and open competition consistent with the standards of 24 C.F.R. § 85.36. (Ord. No. 86-23, 9-2-86; Ord. No. 88-28, § 1, 11-7-88; Ord. No. 88-32, 11-21-88; Ord. No. 90-13, § 1, 7-2-90; Ord. No. 2003-15, § 1, 4-7-03; Ord. No. 2003-23, § 1, 7-21-03) Editor's note— Ord. No. 88-32, adopted Nov. 21, 1988, amended this section by adding provisions designated by the editor as subsection (b), with the existing provisions being designated subsection (a). Sec. 8-15. - Responsibilities of city finance director relating to ad valorem property taxes. The city finance director shall be responsible for the collection of all special assessments and ad valorem property taxes, penalties, interest, and other costs and charges thereon due to the city. (Ord. No. 2003-24, § 6, 8-18-03) Sec. 8-16. - Procedure for collecting special assessments and ad valorem taxes. (a) The city finance director shall cause a bill to be issued to each delivered to the last address shown for each taxpayer on the county tax digest. Failure on the part of the taxpayer to receive a bill shall not constitute grounds for late payment, or failure to pay the tax. The tax bill contemplated herein shall adequately describe the property subject to the tax and list its fair market value as assessed. The bill shall also state the millage rate as adopted and the amount of the tax due. The bill shall also state the date after which taxes shall be considered in default and subject to the collection measures as set forth in this section. (b) Tax bills for property also subject to a special assessment levied by the city shall include, in addition to the information contained in subsection (a) above, a separate sum due as a result of the special assessment. Said tax bill shall further include an adequate description of the basis for said special assessment and the legal authority providing for same. (c) At any time after the last day for the payment of taxes or special assessments have arrived, the city finance director shall cause written notice to be sent to each delinquent taxpayer, or delinquent property owner in the case of a special assessment, of the fact that payment for same is due in full immediately and that failure to pay said tax or special assessment shall result in the city finance director causing an execution to be issued for same and recorded on the county deed records. Upon expiration of thirty (30) days from the aforesaid notice, the city finance director shall issue executions for nonpayment of taxes or special assessments. The execution shall include the following information: (1) The defendant in fi. fa. (the property owner); (2) The year(s) of taxes or special assessments due for which the execution is to be issued; (3) A description of the property sufficient to put interested parties on notice; and (4) All amounts of money due, including the tax, applicable special assessments, penalties, execution costs, and interest. (d) When a properly issued tax execution or special assessment is lost or destroyed, an alias tax execution or special assessment may be issued by the city finance director and such alias tax execution or special assessment shall have the same force and effect as the lost or destroyed original. (Ord. No. 91-3, § 3, 1-21-91; Ord. No. 93-32, § 2, 11-15-93; Ord. No. 2003-24, § 7, 8-18-03; Ord. No. 2005-31, § 2, 12-5-05) Sec. 8-17. - Levy of executions, sale of real and personal property to satisfy unpaid taxes and assessments. (a) The city finance director shall cause all executions issued to be placed in the hands of the police chief for collection or levy and sale of the property. The police chief shall exercise his best efforts to collect the full amount of taxes and assessments due, together with all interest, penalties, and any costs due thereon, from the defendant in fi. fa. In the event the police chief is unable to do so, the police chief shall levy the execution on a sufficient amount of the defendant in fi. fa.'s property, whether real or personal, to satisfy the obligations due at a sale to be held and conducted in accordance with this section. (b) The police chief is hereby designated as the marshal of the city and delegated the duties as set forth herein. The police chief shall be subject to being ruled for money in his hands arising from the public sale of any property pursuant to process issued by the municipality. After first paying the city finance director the amount due on the process under which the sale was made, the marshal shall pay any surplus, should such exist, to any lawful claimant holding an interest subordinate to the lien for taxes. Should there still exist a surplus after all subordinate claims are satisfied, the remainder shall be paid over to the defendant in fi. fa. (c) Whenever any real property is levied upon for taxes or assessments, it shall be the marshal's duty before proceeding to advertise the property for sale to give twenty (20) days' written notice of the levy to the record owner(s) of the property and to the holder of each secured interest holder of record. The twenty-day period shall begin to run from the time the notice is personally delivered or, when delivered by registered or certified mail with return receipt requested, from the date of mailing. The notice shall contain a description of the land levied upon, the name of the owner(s) of the land, the year(s) for which the taxes were assessed, and a statement of the amount of the taxes due, together with accrued costs. The marshal shall keep a copy of the notice on which he shall enter the date the notice was delivered or mailed and how, where, and to whom the notice was delivered. The marshal shall file the copy with the city finance director.
